title: coronavirus live news updates cases
story: UP to  Tube stations across London are closed from today until further notice in a bid to slow the spread of coronavirus.The rest of the capitals transport network will be scaled back from tomorrow with the Waterloo  City line shut completely and Night Tube services scrapped.It comes as the UKs cases of coronavirus rise to , and the death toll hits .The Government wants to ramp up testing to , per day over the next few weeks, up from the current , per day capacity.Supermarkets all over the country are being left barren as people stock up and go into isolation - and all schools are set to close on Friday.China has reported NO fresh cases of coronavirus in the epicentre of the outbreak - signalling a potential turning point in the global fight against the deadly disease.Chinas health ministry said on Thursday that results over the past  hours showed no new diagnoses in Wuhan or surrounding Hubei province.Meanwhile in the UK,Read our live blog for all the latest coronavirus news and updates.A Victorian fort built a mile out to sea to protect the UK from invasion could become the ultimate luxury home for a millionaire looking to self-isolate.No Mans Land Fort # which can only be reached by helicopter or boat # was previously a four-star hotel with  en suite bedrooms, staff quarters and five themed bars.Now the fort could become a single luxury house after millionaire businessman Mike Clare applied for planning permission to convert it.No Mans, Spitbank, and Horse Sand forts were all built in the Solent just a mile off the coast of Portsmouth, Hants, the base of the Royal Navy.And now No Mans fort could be the perfect isolation spot for Brits as thousands are currently self-isolating at home while the pandemic grips hold of the UK.Britains energy suppliers have joined with the Government to launch an emergency package which ensures that vulnerable customers are able to keep the lights on through the coronavirus crisis. Customers with pre-payment metres who are unable to leave their house can now speak to their supplier to get other options. It could include sending someone  to top up their card, having a pre-loaded gas or electricity card sent to them in the post, or having funds added to their credit. Customers who cannot afford to pay their bills will get support from their supplier, the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy has said. Those in financial distress could get their debt repayments and bill payments reassessed paused or reduced where needed, and no credit metres will be disconnected during the outbreak.China’s top coronavirus expert says #herd immunity# has ZERO chance of curbing pandemic because it’s too infectious.Dr Zhong Nanshan criticised the policy whereby where a large portion of the public are exposed to the disease in order to build up resistance.Englands chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said a herd immunity approach could be beneficial in preventing another more aggressive outbreak of Covid-.The thinking shaped the government’s decision to avoid draconian measures, such as the lockdown in Italy.But it has now dramatically changed tack and closed schools amid fears many more people than originally thought could die as the death toll reaches .“Herd immunity wont solve the problem,” said Dr Zhong.“We dont have the evidence to prove thatyou are infected once, you would be immune for le. Our next step is to develop effective vaccines, which requires global cooperation.”Transport for London said it will run a reduced service in the capital from Thursday. Up to  stations which do not interchange with other lines closed on the Tube network. Stations which could be affected include: Bakerloo line: Lambeth North, Regents Park, Warwick Avenue, Kilburn Park, Charing Cross Central line: Holland Park, Queensway, Lancaster Gate, Chancery Lane, Redbridge Circle line: Bayswater, Great Portland Street, Barbican District line: Bow Road, Stepney Green, Mansion House, Temple, St Jamess Park, Gloucester RoadJubilee line: Swiss Cottage, St Johns Wood, Bermondsey, Southwark Northern line: Tuffnell Park, Chalk Farm, Mornington Crescent, Goodge Street, Borough, Clapham South, Tooting Bec, South Wimbledon, HampsteadPiccadilly line: Caledonian Road, Arsenal, Covent Garden, Hyde Park Corner, Bounds Green, Manor House Victoria line: Pimlico, Blackhorse RoadKim Kardashian West says she is missing her sisters as the family isolates separately during the coronavirus outbreak. The reality TV star urged fans stay inside and not to ignore warnings about Covid-. A state of emergency has been declared in Calornia while according to the most recent figures for Los Angeles County, where Kardashian West lives,  people have tested positive for the virus. While isolating, Kardashian West, , said she found a new picture of her and younger sister Kendall Jenner and told fans she was finding the enforced break from her family dficult. She wrote on Instagram: #I was organising my photos in my phone and found this and miss my sisters but we are all social distancing and staying away from each other all separately self quarantined. #Its hard but we have to do this for our safety and for everyone s. PLEASE do not ignore the severity of the warnings to stay inside to stop the spread of this virus. We will all get through this! togetherapart.#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: not time discredit government coronavirus strategy
story: Instead, a handful of broadcasters used precious air time to promote a motley crew of “scientists” desperately hoping to make their names discrediting the Government’s strategy.To those who don’t understand virology, not taking the same draconian measures as other countries may seem odd.But the Prime Minister is acting on the advice of Sir Patrick Vallance and Chris Whitty — eminent doctors ideally equipped to deal with the pandemic.Of course, their superior expertise shouldn’t exempt them from all scrutiny.And, given the stakes, the Government MUST publish the details of its modelling to put minds at rest and give expert virologists a chance to have their say.But puffed-up PhD students with an axe to grind are a far cry from professional epidemiologists.And British broadcasters should know better than to let them spread panic.ACCESS to education is one of the pillars of a civilised society.But because schools are excluding weaker pupils to avoid poor results harming their position in the league tables, a growing number of children are denied that basic right.The consequences of this folly are enormous.It’s estimated that every year-group of permanently excluded pupils costs us £.billion extra on education, health and welfare benefits.And, just as worryingly,  per cent of children in young offender institutions had been excluded while  per cent of prisoners were suspended or excluded.We get that children who struggle academically can be tough on over-stretched teachers.But education shouldn’t be about survival of the fittest.And it’s often the weakest pupils who need school most.Dumping them on the scrapheap of society isn’t fair on anyone.AMID horror and uncertainty, British people are displaying extraordinary kindness, camaraderie and bravery.Each time the Government announces it’s taking another step to keep us safe, Brits have demonstrated that they are listening — and understand the gravity of the situation.Instead of complaining about missed holidays and football games, they’ve quickly and quietly got on with what needs to be done. Shopkeepers — worrying about their own futures — have given out free hand sanitiser and tinned goods to elderly locals.Neighbours have rallied around those most at risk from the disease.This — not needless shelf-clearing — is Britain at its best. Our journalists strive for accuracy title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trust health service staff coronavirus
story: All along he has followed the best advice of our foremost experts on ­epidemics. They said that would evolve as the situation worsened — and yesterday it was toughened dramatically.National unity is key. We must take to heart the self-isolation and lockdowns — both for those already with symptoms and those without. Likewise the “advice” not to go to pubs, restaurants or cinemas.Our lives will be very dferent for months. Britain will barely resemble the country we love. But we can all play our part in seeing off this catastrophe, minimising the disease’s spread and giving the NHS every chance to save lives.The Sun will raise just one doubt:It still seems inconsistent that families must avoid non-essential social contact, but continue packing the children off to school. We know the NHS would be hit hardhealth workers stayed home to look after their kids. But a school skeleton staff could surely supervise them.Only the wartime generation has experienced a crisis this grave. We have to put our faith politically in the newly elected government tasked with facing it down — and the experts around them.Even more importantly we must trust our health service and back its magnicent and selfless staff. You can do that today by emailing iloveNHS@the-sun or by using the form below. We’ll print your messages.The NHS will need every ounce of support the nation can give, evenit just means dutully staying put in our homes.  THE six days since the Budget seem like ten years.Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s admirable debut last Wednesday is all but irrelevant. Its apparently huge bailouts to mitigate the virus will be nowhere near enough. Its growth forecasts are toast.Britain’s decisive response, including the Bank of England slashing the base rate hours earlier, was praised around the world. Others followed suit. But vastly more will now be needed.Evenit lasts no more than a few months — still a big— Covid- is a gargantuan shock to the global economy.Hundreds of thousands of healthy businesses here face oblivion. Their workers may face the dole. Major ­airlines could go bust within weeks.The Government will have to borrow staggering sums to keep them afloat — dishing out grants, tax breaks, business rates relief, interest-free loans, boosted sick pay and more.But we will add this: This is a ­calamity we must ALL face together.If corporations make staff take the pain while fatcat execs sail through it financially unscathed, there will be hell to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus how work from home
story: In a speech given by PM Boris Johnson this week, along with a number of other measures put in place, Brits were told to work from home.Staying in your pyjamas and slippers all day may be tempting, but getting washed and dressed wont just feel good, it will put you in the best frame of mind to take on the day you have ahead.Its important to stick to your usual working hours when working from home. You will be expected to start your day at the same time as you would normally arrive in your office or workplace, and finish at the same time.Although creating a solid routine when working from home is essential, it is important that the process doesnt become tedious. To stay on top of things you should take regular screen breaks - get up and stretch those muscles to avoid getting aches and pains. Research has shown that short breaks throughout the day are more beneficial than less frequent, longer breaks.If youre a sociable person by nature and miss the daily hustle and bustle of the office, being at home away from your pals can get you down. But being away from the office doesnt mean you have to skip your daily interactions with your friends. Pick up the phone and have a chat with your colleagues throughout the day, or Skype instead of sending an email when working on a joint project.When working from home, it may be dficult to separate work time from your own time and merge them as one.Whatever system you and your team communicate on, be sure to turn it off once your hours are complete. Keeping it on outside these hours can wear you down.Without eating properly throughout the day, your energy levels will decrease and youll end up feeling sluggish and unproductive. When at work, we have set times to eat that wont be in place at home. Set aside enough time through your working day to make sure youre not trying to race through the hours on an empty stomach. Working at home doesnt mean you are alone, and there are many ways to keep in contact with your colleagues and teamyou ever get stuck or need help getting through tasks. Many Tech companies have created apps or software so you can get the assistance you need throughout the day no matter where you are.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: all schools uk closed from friday coronavirus
story: BRITAIN’S schools were last night ordered to close from Friday with all exams cancelled in the war on coronavirus.The shutdown, until summer at the earliest, is the Government’s most drastic move yet to slow down the pandemic.But a skeleton school service will remain to care for the children of key workers on the front line.The service will run for NHS staff, police and other blue light services and delivery drivers — estimated at hundreds of thousands. Their kids will continue to get childcare throughout the Easter holidays too.It is the first nationwide school shutdown in modern history.The only similar move was when schools in London shut as pupils were evacuated at the start of World War Two.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson announced the move in the Commons at the same time as the Prime Minister at No .Boris Johnson promised the one million  and -year-olds due to take GCSEs and A-levels they will not be penalised.He insisted: “We will make sure their progress is not impeded.“We will make sure in time they get the qualications they need.”Parents will also get free meals or vouchers for .million children who qualy for school dinners.Mr Johnson also promised that schools already providing free meals will be reimbursed.He added: “I want to thank families for their sacrice at this dficult time. I want to thank the whole country for the efforts people are making to comply with these measures.”Quizzed on how long the school closures will last, the PM would only say: “We will try to keep it to an absolute minimum. I wish I could give you an answer for how long it is going to be.”He insisted schools are still safe places for key workers’ kids.And he explained their closure for most was because children, who suffer the least symptoms from the virus, can also be some of the most virulent spreaders.Mr Johnson said: “The objective is to slow the spread of the virus and we judge it is the right moment to do that.”He added: “Hitherto the advice has been that we should keep schools openpossible in order to reduce the pressure on the NHS and on all other public services.“But I have always been very clear that this is a balanced judgment and one that we have kept under constant review.“So looking at the curve of the disease and at where we are now — we think now we must apply further downward pressure on that upward curve by closing schools.”But he added childcare for key workers’ children is “crucial to make sure the critical parts of the economy keep ing.” Ministers will publish a full list of who has been designated a key worker today.Prince George and Princess Charlotte were sent home from their London prep school yesterday.The school closures were welcomed by teachers’ unions.National Education Union joint general secretary Kevin Courtney said: “It is better for this to take place in an ordered way than the chaotic pattern of closures that was developing”.The PM had faced a growing clamour to take action after countries around the world, including France and Italy, ordered a schools shutdown.Scotland and Wales had already announced schools would shut on Friday.Before the announcement many head teachers were being forced to shut or partially shut because so many staff were in self-isolation.The Harris Academy Trust partially shut  of its schools.Diverse Academies Trust said it had shut all  of its schools across Nottinghamshire and Lincolnshire.Paul Tarn, chief executive of Delta Academy Trust, which runs  schools, told The Sun they had been drawing up contingency plans in case they were told to only open for key workers’ kids.The chain is sending out , text books so pupils can study at home. It is considering keeping some schools open for longer hours and even at weekends to give extra support to key workers.Mr Tarn said: “Our teachers have been teaching extra classes — showing some proper British spirit.“We are taking a very strong line in doing our bit in support.”He added: “We want to make sure those workers out on the front line have support for their children at schools.”CAN you get time off workyour children’s school is closed Parents are entitled to take time off to look after children — and you can’t face disciplinary action or lose your job.This is known as “dependant leave” which allows time off to deal with an unexpected problem or emergency.The downside is that you may not be paid, unless your employer agrees to.You may be able to negotiate paid time off, but it is down to your employer.Workers may also be able to negotiate taking time off as holiday or lieu days.Your employer cannot make you work extra hours or make up the missed time.CAN you work from home or request flexible working The UK government has said everyone should work from home, where possible.This is only advice, so whether you are allowed to will depend on your employer.All employees have the right to request flexible working — not just parents.But you must have been with the same employer for at least  weeks.Employers must assess the advantages and disadvantages, as well as hold a meeting with you to discuss the request.Flexible working can include working from home, flexitime and job sharing.Employers can reject the request for a number of reasons, including costs to the business and getting your work covered.

title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: princess charlotte prince george school coronavirus
story: PRINCE George and Princess Charlotte will now be home-schooled amid the Coronavirus pandemic.The young royals, third and fourth in line to the throne, will be taught at home following advice from their £,-a-year school.Thomass in Battersea are encouraging all parents including Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, to remove children from classes by Friday.The measure is precautionary and no one has tested positive for the disease.Prince George, six, is coming to the end of his second year at the school and four-year-old Princess Charlotte joined her big brother last September.Several children at Thomass four schools, in Battersea, Clapham, Kensington and Fulham, have been tested for the virus but no one has been found positive for Coronavirus, it is understood.A spokesperson for Thomas’s London Day Schools said: Due to the increasing numbers of children and staff being absent from school due to the Coronavirus situation, Thomas’s London Day Schools have decided to move to remote learning from Friday  March.From this date the curriculum will be taught through online learning s and we have asked parents to keep their children at home and to access their lessons through this system.This will ensure that children have continuity of learning when they are unable to attend school.In cases where families are not in a position to keep their children at home , the school will remain physically open until the last day of term, Thursday, th March.We appreciate the support of our school community as we continue to provide the best possible solution for our pupils during these challenging times.The co-education school has a theatre, gymnasium, ballet room and pottery room and two libraries and rooftop playground.It has  boys and girls aged between four and -years-old and charges £, a year.Former pupils include model Cara Delavigne and singer Florence Welch.For all the latest news, tips and information - title: susanna reid good morning britain steve barclay
story: The fuming Good Morning Britain presenter - who is home for two weeks after her son developed symptoms - laid into the Chief Secretary to the Treasury for failing to keep frontline workers safe.At the moment Britain is only testing people in intensive care in hospital, and investigating certain outbreaks of the disease.If Brits have mild symptoms they are being told to stay home, but they wont be tested.She blasted when appearing by video-link on todays show: WHY arent we testing every single health care worker who is having to self isolate for  days under the new Government advice I could get hold of a test privately for a test for £I wanted to.Why isnt the Government buying up all those tests to prioritise tests for healthcare workers The GMB host said there were loads of worried NHS workers who have got in touch over concerns.Mr Barclay told her we are already testing massively and we are ramping it up.But he admitted that more needed to be done, saying: We are title: manchester bomber salman abedi lift cctv
story: Twisted Abedi can be seen in the lt making his way up to the foyer of the Manchester Arena on May , , where thousands of children and adults were spilling out of an Ariana Grande concert.The warped jihadi was captured on CCTV adjusting wires under his jacket that were strapped to the homemade explosive.Just one hour later, the -year-old flicked the switch on the bomb - sending shrapnel through the foyer killing himself and  innocent gig-goers in a terror attack that horried the nation.The haunting CCTV was released after brother Hashem Abedi, , was yesterday found guilty of mass murder over his part in the atrocity.Hashem, who was , miles away in Libya at the time of the blast, was the ringleader in the attack and helped his brother source nuts and bolts to pack into the IED.The monster denied he was a terrorist - but the Old Bailey heard how he was every bit as responsible as his older brother as he plotted further bloodshed across the world.Heartbroken families of the victims wept as jurors took less than five hours to convict him  counts of murder, one count of attempted murder encompassing the injured survivors, and conspiring with his brother to cause explosions.But there was fury as coward Hashem Abedi refused to appear in court for the verdict and avoided the dock to give evidence during the seven-week trial.Daryl Price, whose son John Atkinson, , was among those killed in the blast, said: The last few weeks have been draining, both mentally and physically, and when the jury read out their decision it felt like somebody had kicked me in the stomach.I was expecting it but it still knocked the wind out of me, I couldnt breathe for a few seconds.I am annoyed that he couldnt make an appearance in court to face those people whose lives he ruined.I had planned to go to London for the verdict, I wanted to look him right in the eye, but he is too much of a coward for that.During his trial, the Old Bailey heard how the sadistic brothers spent months hatching the bloodbath - using bank accounts of pals to buy chemicals online.The pair used their mums £-a-week benefit payments, which she continued to receive after she left the UK for Libya, to buy tools.They flew back to Libya when friends noticed signs they had been radicalised but just days before the attack, Salman Abedi ed to Manchester.Haunting CCTV caught him skulking around the arena at a Take That gig on a practice run.And Hashem Abedi, a former electronics student, continued advising him by phone — and is believed to have been the last person he spoke to when he stopped at a bench on his way to the gig.Salman later left for the nearby Arndale shopping centre where he bought batteries and a blue Kangol suitcase so he could move his bomb-making equipment to the flat he rented in Manchester city centre.He was then caught in chilling CCTV images with a rucksack packed with thousands of nuts just  seconds before the deadly blast.Salman Abedi waited for around an hour in the Manchester Arena foyer before parents and children left the gig at .pm.One minute later, he detonated the bomb as  people stood in the City Room - with  declared dead at the scene.Among debris found after the blast were , nyloc nuts,  flanged nuts,  plain nuts and  fragments from Salman Abedi and his victims.There were also screws recovered by investigators but they were so damaged they couldnt be counted.Images shown to jurors also feature charred clothing recovered from the scene and labels from vegetable oil used to make the bomb.Among other debris were fragments from a money tin decorated with the design of a £ note also used to maim innocent gig-goers.The youngest victim, Saffie-Rose Roussos, eight, suffered more than  external injuries, with  metal nuts in her body, and died from blood loss due to multiple injuries.Student Chloe Rutherford, , suffered more than  injuries, including a brain injury which would have left her immediately unconscious, the court was told.Jurors also heard Salman Abedis body was later recovered in four parts and he had to be identied by his DNA and fingerprints.Forensic investigators later found more than , nuts from the homemade bomb at the scene.After the blast, Hashem Abedi denied he was an extremist but the court heard his DNA was discovered in a Nissan Micra used to store packs of nails for the bomb.Saman Abedi was captured in CCTV footage ing to the car after his Take That practice run four days before the terror attack.The brothers were born in Manchester to Libyan parents and booked one-way tickets the country in April  after stockpiling chemicals used to make the homemade explosive.Salman Abedi then ed to his native Manchester on May  to carry out the atrocity.Hashem repeatedly denied any knowledge of his brother’s plot and suggested he had been conned into believing the bomb parts were for household use.He was arrested by Libyan authorities soon after the attack but an extradition bid proved dficult because of the civil war raging in the North African country.The Sun on Sunday revealed the extradition bid cost UK taxpayers £,.Detective Chief Superintendent Simon Barraclough said: If you look at these two brothers, they are not kids caught in the headlights of something they dont understand.These two men are the real deal, these are proper jihadis - you do not walk into a space like the Manchester Arena and kill yourself with an enormous bomb like that, taking  innocent lives with you,you are not a proper jihadist.He was with his brother throughout the entire process of making this explosive and building this bomb, I believe he provided encouragement right up to the end.This was all about the sick ideology of Islamic State and this desire for martyrdom.Victoria Higgins, from law firm Slater and Gordon, which represented  of the bereaved families, said after the verdicts: “Families have waited a long time to see Hashem Abedi face justice for his crimes and I think the overwhelming emotion for most will be one of relief that he cannot hurt anyone .“It has been incredibly painful for them to hear, in detail, what happened to their loved ones and the calculated way in which the Abedi brothers plotted to end their lives.”Abedi will be sentenced at a later date.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: london lockdown coronavirus
story: BORIS Johnson tonight hinted London could face a coronavirus lockdown - with extra travel restrictions for Brits in the capital.Sources close to City Hall said today that the Government is preparing fresh legislation to give them the power to stop gatherings, and keep Londoners inside.It could include measures to stop Londoners leaving their homes except to go to the supermarket or pharmacy, The Sun has been told.Downing Street said today that ministers could use existing laws to keep iniduals in isolation for their own safety.And the emergency powers could come as early as Friday, though sources stressed the plans were not imminent.Boris Johnson said this evening when directly asked about a London lockdown and whether peoples restriction could be limited: Weve always said that we are going to do the right measures at the right time.He told the country this evening: We live in a land of liberty, we don’t tend to impose those sort of restriction.But I have to tell you: we will rule nothing out. We will bring forward further and faster measures where necessary.Measures like this are being considered because London is the worst affected area in the country - with  cases and  deaths.In the country as a whole there are now , cases - up by more than  in  hours.The PM said earlier this week that the virus was spreading faster in London than other parts of the country - and people in the capital should take extra note of the new rules.No today did not deny that extra measures were coming specically for London.A spokesperson said: We have set out the steps necessary at this point in time. But we will be guided by the scientic and medical advice to make sure we take the right steps at the right time.We will do whatever it is required to keep the public safe.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said earlier that London may have to take more stringent measures because of its outbreak curve.She said: It will not be the case that all parts of the UK are at the same place on the curve at the same time.We know London is ahead of the rest of us so we may see more stringent measures than even those that we have announced so far, being taken but they will not necessarily be taken in all parts of the country at the same time.Earlier this week Boris announced strict new measures - telling everyone to work from homethey can, and to stop going out and socialising with friends and family.But insiders said the Government were alarmed that Londoners were ignoring calls to avoid pubs and restaurants, and further action needed to be taken to stop the spread.Legislation could allow the Government to shut down premises too.New figures from Transport for London show a drop of  per cent on the tubes and buses at the start of March already.And only one inidual per household is permitted to leave at once.They have to carry paperwork which confirms your identity and address - and explains the reason why you are travelling.Cultural and sporting activities are banned and big public events are also barred.Restaurants and bars are closed, while public transport is severely limited.And they face an on-the-spot of  eurosthey do not have the documents on them at the time.Ministers have deployed , cops to enforce the lockdown.ITALYMeanwhile, Italy has faced a similar lockdown since March  - where no one is allowed out except to to get food, petrol and medicine, and have to be healthy to do so.All schools, restaurants, bars and cafes are shut, and anyone that does venture out has to fill in a set of forms too.Italy has the second-highest number of diagnosed cases in the world, with , infections and more than , deaths.There are fines of up to  euros on the spo and six months in prisonthey are found to break the rules.Thousands of people so far have received a ticking off so far.SPAINDeadly coronavirus has seen Spain gradually grind to a halt.All non-essential venues have been shut down and people told only to leave homeabsolutely necessary for food or medication.The country, which has reported nearly , cases and nearly  deaths, and today closed all hotels and demanded tourists leave urgently.The government shuttered schools on March  and announced an official state of emergency on Friday.All bars and restaurants have closed and there are fines of up to , euros for disobeying the lockdown ban.Spaniards can also be jailed for up to a year.Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez has warned his people they faced very dficult weeks of sacrices ahead.And today it was announced that schools in Wales and Scotland would shut on Friday.Englands announcement is set to come later today.Boris told PMQs in the Commons: The House should expect decisions to be taken imminently on schools. For all the latest news, tips and information - title: brits random unwanted items shelves panic buying
story: BRITS have been panic buying food as the coronavirus pandemic worsens - but it appears not all food will do for some fussy eaters.People have been sharing snaps of certain items left on the shelves, shunned by even panicked shoppers in desperate times.It seems that plant-based milk isnt what Brits want to take into the bunkers with them, nor are the controversial Fig Rolls.Both these, plus tins of scotch broth and pricier Lloyd Grossman sauces were left behind on shelves otherwise stripped bare.Fancier kinds of pasta were also not wanted, with buckwheat penne left stacked on Sainsburys shelves and lentil pasta discarded.Fresh fruit and veg has been snapped up, but fennel and parsley went untouched - with later shoppers tweeting to askthere is a dish they could create from them.And even in fearful times pineapple topped pizza - the greatly debated dish - were left in piles in the frozen aisle.It comes as , people have now caught coronavirus and  people have died from the infection.London is braced to enter a lockdown within days - with extra travel restrictions for Brits in the capital.Sources close to City Hall say the Government is preparing a fresh bill to give them the power to stop gatherings, and keep Londoners inside.The Government and food bosses called for an end to panic buying — and ministers signalled they may now ration certain productsthe mob mentality in stores continues.Health Secretary Matt Hancock implored selfish shoppers to “behave responsibly” and “consider the impact that their stocking up might have on others”.He spoke after video emerged of customers lining up with trolleys for up to  minutes before supermarkets opened.Stores then joined forces to write an unprecedented open letter reassuring customers they can cope.Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Morrisons reported empty shelves. A Costco outlet in Chingford, North East London, was forced to shut and call police after a stampede.Online sales also went into meltdown, with delivery slots filled until April.And today Sainsburys will limit sales of every item in its stores as it tries to stamp out panic-buying.Customers will be able to buy a maximum of three of any grocery item and two of the most popular products, such as toilet paper, soap and UHT milk.And older shoppers will have stores to themselves for the first hour of opening from tomorrow - plus get priority home delivery slots from Monday.Prime Minister Boris Johnson instructed the UK to work from home and practise social isolation to stop the spread of the killer bug.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Yesterday it was announced the Ministry of Defence is planning to deploy , medics to help the struggling NHS deal with the coronavirus pandemic.GPs, surgeons and nurses are being lined up as part of drastic measures to stop the spread of the killer bug.It is feared many businesses will not survive the lockdown, as customers stay at home.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fort self isolation coronavirus lockdown
story: A VICTORIAN fort built a mile out to sea to protect the UK from invasion could become the ultimate luxury home for a millionaire looking to self-isolate.No Mans Land Fort - which can only be reached by helicopter or boat - was previously a four-star hotel with  en suite bedrooms, staff quarters and five themed bars.Now the fort could become a single luxury house after millionaire businessman Mike Clare applied for planning permission to convert it.No Mans, Spitbank, and Horse Sand forts were all built in the Solent just a mile off the coast of Portsmouth, Hants, the base of the Royal Navy.And now No Mans fort could be the perfect isolation spot for Brits as thousands are currently self-isolating at home while the pandemic grips hold of the UK.As of Wednesday afternoon, coronavirus cases hit , in Britain in the biggest daily leap yet - with  already killed by the deadly bug.Cases jumped by  cases in  hours while Scotland recorded another death today.The forts off the south coast could now be an attractive purchase after it was announced they were to be sold off by Mr Clare - founder of the bed company Dreams - in September last year.It was thought No Mans and Spitbank Forts could fetch £ million together.The planning application for No Mans — which also has a lighthouse, laser battle play area, restaurant and spa — is asking the Isle of Wight Council for permission to change the hotel into a single residential property.Plans put forward by Mr Clares holding company, Clarenco, would see the building converted from a hotel into a house with at least  bedrooms in the middle of the Solent.As a hotel, No Mans Land Fort had capacity for  people and cost up to £ per night.Guests were able to arrive by boat or on the fort’s helipad, before drinking in its five themed bars and relaxing in its rooftop hot pools.It has  ensuite guest bedrooms and staff quarters.The fort has , sq ft over four floors and includes a lighthouse with private dining, rooftop hot tubs, sauna, fire pit, hot pool and helipad.Mr Clare, from Beaconsfield, Bucks, bought Spitbank Fort in  and later bought Horse Sand and No Man’s forts in .The three forts were originally ordered by then-Prime Minister Henry Temple, the third Viscount Palmerston, in the mid-s after concerns were raised over the strength of the French Navy.However, when they were never actually used in war, despite also having submarine defences strung between them during the Second World War, they become known as Palmerstons Follies.They boast ft tall granite walls and were used as temporary army barracks but were decommissioned by the Ministry of Defence in .Comments on the application can be made until April .To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: spot huge carpet python hiding familys kitchen larder
story: Queenslander Stuart McKenzie floored Aussies by challenging them to find the hiding place of a sneaky carpet python - which can grow up to  feet.On the Sunshine Coast Snake Catchers Facebook page, he posted a pic of the well-concealed constrictor, inviting people to Spot the Snake.Stuart added: Amongst all the [coronavirus] panic I think a good old fashion game of Spot the Snake is what we all need. See how you go finding this one and bonus pointsyou can guess the species.We will continue to provide a   snake catching services across the whole Sunshine Coast, Noosa and Deception Bay areas despite the CoronaVirus. Snakes dont stop for no virus [sic]. We will start employing distancing at snake calls but lets be honest we already make sure our customers stand well clear of us when we are catching the snakes.In the end, he received more than  comments, as people puzzled over the stealthy creatures whereabouts.A defeated Phil Trevan replied: I hate spot the snake, I have never worked out one yet.Others responded by circling potential hiding spots. Bob Trezise joked: Top right, deadly green tinsel adder   while a stumped Connie Carey posted its a goodie. Cannot see it.Jo Helenius begged: Answer pls it is doing my head in lol.In the end Stuart relented, and provided the answer - the carpet python was hiding between cardboard and plastic storage boxes.Shahni Waerea replied: The moral of this story is... snakes love clutter.They live in open forests, rainforests, coastal heaths, rural lands, park lands and suburban gardens.Active both day and night, carpet pythons can be encountered on the ground, in trees or buildings - particularly chicken pens, barns and attics.Athough non-venomous, tetanus protection is recommended following bites.Male Carpet Snakes have been observed fighting in spring.The species feed on frogs, lizards, birds, mammals, and can grow up to .m long.Source: Queensland Museum  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus deliberately cough reporter argentina
story: SHOCKING footage shows a “coronavirus-riddled” bus passenger deliberately coughing and sneezing on a journalist on live TV.The disgusting clip, taken from a news report by Argentinian website Cronica, was filmed at a bus station in the country’s capital Buenos Aires.Correspondent Marco Bustamante was reporting on the exodus of foreign nationals ing to their home countries amid the virus outbreak when the incident occurred.As he spoke, the culprit approached him and accused him of lying before declaring “I have coronavirus”, Cronica reports.He can be seen leaping from his seat and walking towards the shocked reporter, coughing and sneezing in his direction.The vile assailant then grins and waves his victim away as he heads back to the bench.Cops were called and rushed to the scene, detaining and isolating the attacker, the website reported.It is not clearhe really was suffering from the deadly disease.South America has seen relatively low virus infection rates so far, but numbers are expected to rise.Argentina has had  confirmed cases, including two deaths.There have been more than , people infected by Covid- around the world, with over , deaths.Sadly the news report is not the first time someone has been filmed deliberately coughing on others since the outbreak began.An outraged Aussie commuter was videoed calling out a woman for purposely spluttering in his direction during a heated row about spreading the bug this month.The spat unfolded on a train in Sydney after a woman apparently let out a cough without properly covering her face.And just weeks ago Thai Airlines cabin crew were filmed tackling a passenger who was accused of deliberately coughing on staff.One airline employee holds the woman in a headlock as others rush to his aid and restrain her, pleading with her to “stay down”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince harry meghan markle urge public come together coronavirus
story: PRINCE Harry and Meghan Markle today urged the public to come together in the face of the coronavirus crisis in a fresh statement on Instagram.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex told their .million followers we are all in this together as the number of global coronavirus cases today surged past ,.The couple posted a quote on their Instagram today, saying: This moment is as true a testament there is to the human spirit.Accompanied by the couples monogrammed H and M, they shared an inspiring message on social media telling their followers to focus on the positive news around them.They said: These are uncertain times. And now, more than ever, we need each other. We need each other for truth, for support, and to feel less alone during a time that can honestly feel quite scary.They went on: How we approach each other and our communities with empathy and kindness is indisputably important right now. Over the coming weeks, this will be our guiding principle.We are all in this together, and as a global community we can support each other through this process – and build a digital neighbourhood that feels safe for every one of us.It comes as the couple ed to Canada this month after completing their final engagements as Royals.The Sussexes had dramatically announced they were quitting the Firm in January - with their last day settled for March  after negotiations with the Queen.And it has been claimed the couple and baby Archie, who is ten months, are now self-isolating in their luxury North American home.There are so many around the world who need support right now, who are working tirelessly to respond to this crisis behind the scenes, on the frontline, or at home. Our willingness, as a people, to step up in the face of what we are all experiencing with COVID- is awe-inspiring.This moment is as true a testament there is to the human spirit. We often speak of compassion.All of our lives are in some way affected by this, uniting each of us globally.How we approach each other and our communities with empathy and kindness is indisputably important right now.Over the coming weeks, this will be our guiding principle. We will be sharing information and resources to help all of us navigate the uncertainty: from posting accurate information and facts from trusted experts, to learning about measures we can take to keep ourselves and our families healthy, to working with organisations that can support our mental and emotional well-being.In addition, we will focus on the inspiring stories of how so many of you around the world are connecting in ways big and small to lt all of us up.We are all in this together, and as a global community we can support each other through this process – and build a digital neighbourhood that feels safe for every one of us.We look forward to sharing more over the days and weeks to come...Meghan said they are grateful, especially Harry, that they could spend time with his family before all this insanity began, an insider said.Meghan saidhas been in contact with the both his father and grandmother. He urged them to stay safe and to take extra precautions.The couple are currently keeping a social distance in a huge waterfront pile, costing £ million, on Vancouver Island.According to the same source, Harry feels a bit helpless and isolated out in the middle of nowhere, but is grateful that they are all together as a family.Meanwhile, Princess Beatrice has been forced to cancel her May wedding due to concerns around the virus.A Buckingham Palace spokesman confirmed: Princess Beatrice and Mr Mapelli Mozzi are very much looking forward to getting married but are equally aware of the need to avoid undertaking any unnecessary risks in the current circumstances.In line with government advice for the UK and beyond, the couple are reviewing their arrangements for th May.They are particularly conscious of government advice in relation to both the wellbeing of older family members and large gatherings of people. Therefore, the planned reception in the Buckingham Palace Gardens will not take place.The couple will carefully consider government advice before deciding whether a private marriage might take place amongst a small group of family and friends.The Queen was today pictured without gloves conducting her last few engagements at Buckingham Palace before she is expected to head to Windsor.The monarch is soon set to leave London and head to Windsor Castle amid the coronavirus crisis.Several royal events will be postponed including all garden parties at the palace and the annual Maundy Service at St George’s Chapel on th April will not go ahead.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sanders suspends campaign after latest defeat to joe biden on super tuesday iii
story: The Vermont Senator reportedly showed extreme anger when he was questioned about his campaign plans by a CNN reporter on Wednesday.When CNN#s Senior Congressional Correspondent Manu Raju asked the -year-old, he replied:  #I#m dealing with a f***ing global crisis. the morning after his disappointing results in primary bids.Bernie#s campaign manager previously Faiz Shakir issued a statement saying he would be #assessing# his campaign.Shakir said #last night did not go the way we wanted,# after Bernie lost three states, according to Axios.The report noted former presidential hopefuls Pete Buttigieg and Michael Bloomberg deactivated their Facebook ads before pulling out of the race.Despite his numerous gaffes on the campaign trail, Biden#s latest victory marks the third consecutive week he has piled up wins after South Carolina last month revived his once-weakened campaign.Sanders# recent comments about Cuba probably doomed him there weeks ago, well before Biden#s South Carolina surge.In a  Minutes interview on February , Sanders praised Cuban dictator Castro for his #massive literacy program.#The -year-old Vermont senator has continued to push on in the  presidential race despite a string of losses to Biden.The coronavirus pandemic has also impacted both Bernie and Biden#s rallies as Americans are urged to avoid large gatherings.Last week, Sanders vowed to #do everything in his power# to stop Donald Trump in his six-minute televised address in Vermont.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mobile morgue westminster london coronavirus
story: A HUGE mobile mortuary has been swtly set up in London to cope with the number of bodies from the coronavirus pandemic.It comes as cases in the UK surged to , with  deaths, as the Prime Minister urged everyone to work from home.Westminster Public Mortuary has space for  bodies, but the expanded tent set up will see this almost doubled - as London becomes the worst hit.Today builders were seen at the site behind Westminster Coroners Court readying for a jump in expected victims.A Westminster council worker at the site today, said the refrigerated racked tent would double the councils capacity.He also said councils were building similar tents to expand capacity as much as possible in the pandemic.Adding: The tent will be up today and will be ready by the weekend.We hopefully wont ever need them. But you saw the numbers of what could happen, so we need to be prepared.A Westminster City Council spokesperson added: We have plans in place to increase the capacity of our mortuary at Horseferry Road as part of a London wide response to the Coronavirusoutbreak.This is a precautionary step and similar arrangements are made during any London wide response to incidents. We hope and trust that this will not be needed but it is sensible to prepare at this stage.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.London is braced to enter a lockdown within days - with extra travel restrictions for Brits in the capital.Sources close to City Hall say the Government is preparing a fresh bill to give them the power to stop gatherings, and keep Londoners inside.The over s, those who are pregnant, and anyone with underlying health conditionsshould try not to leave their homesthey can, and avoid crowded spaces immediately.This will continue for the “long haul” – likely weeks or months.And those with severe illnesses like cancermust start cocooning themselves in their homes and get food delivered in from this weekend.Earlier this week Boris Johnson said: Clearly what we’re announcing today is a very substantial change in the way we want people to live their lives, and I can’t remember anything like it in my letime.I don’t think there’s really been anything like it in peacetime.It’s a very considerable, psychological, behavioural change that we’re asking you, we’re asking the public, the nation to do.But I’ve absolutely no doubt that we can do it, that we can do it together.A team from Imperial College London, led by Professor Neil Ferguson, said the new tighter controls could limit deaths to around , - with the leading professor admitting the best case scenario would still see tens of thousands die.The country could be stuck in a state of permanent outbreak and lockdown until a vaccine is found - title: coronavirus school closures england uk
story: SCHOOLS across England, Scotland and Wales will be closed by the end of the week as Britain desperately tries to contain the coronavirus outbreak. Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Wednesday that he would be closing tens of thousands of schools this Friday due to the crisis.The closures will start this Friday afternoon, with no lessons planned once theyve left.Schools will be closed for normal pupils, but kept open for the children of key workers.This means parents working in the NHS, emergency services and other essential fields will still be able to send their kids off while they work.The move comes two weeks before kids are meant to break up for the Easter break.And they may not reopen before the six-week summer break too, with the Education Secretary today saying they would be closed until further notice.Schools will be closed for at least five weeks.Mr Williamson announced the closures this evening, and claimed keeping schools open would no longer be in the best interests of children and teachers.He explained the scientic evidence had changed,  and the move was at the forefront of Britains fightback against the virus.The Tory MP also revealed assessments and exams  were both cancelled, and there will be performance tables this academic year.He said: This will be for all children except to those of key workers and children who are most vulnerable.The scientic evidence shows these settings are safe for this small number of children to continue attending.But asking others to stay away will go towards helping us slow the spread of this virus.Examples of these key workers include NHS staff, police and delivery drivers who need to be able to go to work.Schools in Scotland and Wales are to close from Friday because of the epidemic.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said schools had just lost too many staff to be able to carry on as normal.She also warned parents not to expect them to be back in time for the summer term.It comes after a title: chinas coronavirus expert herd immunity
story: CHINA’S leading coronavirus expert has said the strategy of “herd immunity” will not work because the disease is too infectious.Dr Zhong Nanshan criticised the policy whereby where a large portion of the public are exposed to the disease in order to build up resistance.Englands chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said a herd immunity approach could be beneficial in preventing another more aggressive outbreak of Covid-.The thinking shaped the government’s decision to avoid draconian measures, such as the lockdown in Italy.But it has now dramatically changed tack and closed schools amid fears many more people than originally thought could die as the death toll reaches .“Herd immunity wont solve the problem,” said Dr Zhong.“We dont have the evidence to prove thatyou are infected once, you would be immune for le. Our next step is to develop effective vaccines, which requires global cooperation.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Last week Sir Patrick outlined the thinking behind the herd immunity approach, which he said was aimed at preventing the virus recurring.“We think this virus is likely to be one that comes year on year, becomes like a seasonal virus,” he said.Communities will become immune to it and thats going to be an important part of controlling this longer term.About  per cent is the sort of figure you need to get herd immunity.But Health Secretary Matt Hancock denied that was the Governments policy, describing it as a scientic concept.The approach had been criticised by a group of scientists from UK universities, who said it risks many more lives than necessary, and was called into question by the World Health Organisation.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lorry drivers coronavirus toilet access
story: LORRY drivers who have been hauling deliveries across the country are being banned from using the bathrooms of the firms they deliver for over fears of spreading coronavirus.Industry bosses have claimed that hundreds of companies across the UK have stopped all drivers from using their bathrooms, forcing some desperate drivers to pee behind bins.Dougie Rankine, the editor of Truck and Driver magazine, has been collating the horric accounts from lorry drivers who have to pee behind bins and poo into carrier bags because companies wont let them use their facilities.He said: Since the panic buying in the last week or so hundreds of companies have banned drivers from entering the premises and using their hand washing facilities.Drivers have been told to pee behind bins and to use portaloos without running water.According to a letter written by Public Health England  there is no public health reason to deny toilets to the drivers.The letter said: There is no public health reason to deny access to toilet facilities to freight driverswho do not have symptoms of cough or high temperature.At this time, it is particularly important that everyone increases the frequency of hand washing, so access to toilet facilities is particularly important.Drivers who have underlying health conditions have been forced to cope with waiting.One driver with colitis, who holds a disability card, was denied access to a firms bathroom.Another driver had no choice but to relieve themselves in bottles after more than four hours of waitingSome truck drivers have even been forced to wait in waiting rooms packed with  other drivers or more.Major supermarkets in the UK have been included in the complaints for cramming drivers into small rooms risking the spread of the deadly bug.Douglas who still drives his own truck said: All I am asking is for drivers to be treated with respect. There is nobody to represent the drivers, they are hopeless.The increase in the number of deliveries have been due to the panic buying across the UK.Panic buyers queued outside supermarkets from am this morning and stripped the shelves bare within just one hour as selfish Brits alarmed by the coronavirus pandemic continue to stockpile against government advice.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Huge queues snaked around supermarkets across the country this morning and aisles were left empty, with just ice cream and chocolate Easter eggs remaining at many major stores.British supermarkets have struggled for two weeks to keep shelves stocked in the face of intense panic buying, despite appeals for calm from supermarket bosses and politicians.Online grocery operations have also been running at capacity.In his daily briefing yesterday evening, the PM urged shoppers to be sensible when buying food.He said: We are absolutely confident our supply chains are working, and will work, and we will get farm to fork food supplies.Therefore people should have no reason to stockpile or panic buy.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has previously implored selfish shoppers to behave responsibly and consider the impact that their stocking up might have on others.

title: northern ireland veterans end witch hunts
story: The landmark offer is being drawn up by ministers as the next chapter in their election vow to end witch-hunt historical investigations, The Sun can reveal.It comes as Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis delighted ageing ex-troops by revealing he plans to rip up the vast majority of police probes into incidents during the Troubles, some of which date back five decades.The Cabinet minister said his action was to match a new law unveiled by the MoD today to slap a time limit of five years on legal pursuits of service personnel on overseas operations.Mr Lewis pledged “equal treatment of Northern Ireland veterans and those who served overseas”.He revealed he is setting up a new commission to rapidly st through the morass of outstanding accusations and claims.Its aim will be to give grieving families long-hoped for answers about their murdered loved ones, but at the same time offer closure to worried veterans in their s and s.Mr Lewis told the Commons in a written statement: “The Government will ensure that the investigations which are necessary are effective and thorough, but quick, so we are able to move beyond the cycle of investigations that has, to date, undermined attempts to come to terms with the past.”But introducing the crucial new caveat, he added: “Only cases in which there is a realistic prospect of a prosecution as a result of new compelling evidence would proceed to a full police investigation.“Cases which do not reach this threshold, or subsequently are not referred for prosecution, would be closed.”Dropping a major hint about his plan to then force their permanent closure in law, he added: “No further investigations or prosecutions would be possible”.The new body is likely to replace the controversial Historical Investigations Unit, which was set to go over more than  killings by ex-Army soldiers through out the conflicts  years.Ministers hope it will last for only one or two years, with outstanding cases against troops dealt with first and wrapped up in a matter of months.When they are closed, the intention is then to give each veteran involved in them a legal undertaking that they are in the clear forevermore - a process that could match the comfort letters sent to IRA terrorists exempting them from prosecution after the Good Friday peace deal in .The sweeping changes – which will be passed in legislation expected next month – would deliver on PM Boris Johnson’s election pledge to end vexatious claims against vets.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur story: BORIS Johnson announced today that all schools will be shut down from Friday until further notice for all children except to those of key workers and vulnerable kids.The official list will be released tomorrow but some of the list we can expect are those from medical professionals and education to name a few.The list is expected to include:The Education Secretary Gavin Williamson promised that free school meals will continue for everyone who needs it - likely in the form of supermarket vouchers.Boris told the nation this evening that the spread was slowing as a result of the draconian measures he put in place this week.The PM explained: We believe the steps we have already taken, together with those I am announcing today, are already slowing the spread of the disease.Although most are grateful for the school closures, ensuring that their children has a less risk of catching coronavirus, there are many parents worried how they will be able to feed their kids.Normally, children in low-income families are on the Free Schools Meals scheme.Yet, have no fear as Education Secretary Gavin Williamson revealed that these families will be put on a national voucher system, whereby they will receive free coupons with monetary value to cover the loss of school meals - and can spend them how they like.Williamson said in yesterdays briefing that schools will be closed until further notice - but would be at least five weeks, taking us until April  at the earliest.The closure comes just two weeks before the Easter break when they would have had a fortnight off.But this break could last until the end of the school year and the summers six-week break.
