title: rishi sunak coronavirus economy meltdown
story: Some have already lost their jobs. Others must now give theirs up to look after their kids, with schools closing.It may be hard for politicians to grasp, but many ordinary people have no savings to tide them over.They are broke NOW. They need to feed themselves and their families NOW.Not at the weekend. Not next week.Even those not yet made redundant by this global economic collapse are petried about how bad this could get.The pub industry alone says hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost imminently without immediate help.Other governments have stepped in. Why has ours been so slow Devising a new system to get tens of billions in lost wages into the right hands is complex. We get that.We also think the “universal income” idea is an ill-considered and permanently ruinous fix.But promises, and a temporary ban on evicting renters, won’t quell the fear.This virus is not the fault of the workers, nor the Government whose draconian restrictions are sound.But with the economy in total meltdown, only the Government now can get Britain paid.Do it today, Rishi.CLOSING schools was grimly inevitable but right. It always seemed odd to keep them open while telling everyone to stay home.The Government must fulfil its pledge to ensure kids on free school meals are fully funded to get fed.We pay tribute to the NHS staff, delivery drivers and social carers whose often low-paid work is so essential that their children WILL still be looked after in school.And our hearts go out to the teenagers whose GCSEs and A-levels will be postponed indefinitely.This is an unprecedented nightmare, blighting their childhoods.We can only help each other endure it.IMAGINE the evil of using a deadly ­pandemic to spread fake news furthering your political or commercial agenda.It should no longer shock us after the Salisbury poisonings.But Kremlin trolls are sowing panic online to undermine the West’s Covid- strategies.Let’s remember that, next time our leaders have to make nice with Putin at the G.Meanwhile, conspiracy cranks say hand sanitiser causes cancer — and charlatans claim their “yoghurt suppositories” or vitamin pills “cure” the virus.Where do they do this with near impunity  That’s right . . .On Facebook, which talks such a good game about policing its site — but is always found wanting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how to keep your kids active
story: ENSURING that your kids do not fall behind with the school closures will be a priority for parents.The Home Education Handbook, by Gill Hines, is full of practical advice and guidance for those having to manage their children’s education at home.Gill says: “It’s important for children and young people to see self-isolation as ‘working from home’, not a holiday.Returning to school will be ­easierthey have kept up some kind of learning routine, evenit is dferent to what they are used to.”Here, Gill reveals ways to ensure that your kids’ school work does not suffer due to the classroom closures.Start by making a timetable - see below. A couple of hours in the morning and another one in the afternoon is plenty, although for young people sitting exams this year they may still need to do some evening work to keep up.Agree the timing for each child with them — and expect them to stick to it. Everyone needs to be dressed and ready when their morning start-time arrives.Near the end of each “work day”, spend a little time together planning the next day’s activities so everyone knows what they have to do.Older children will probably have at least some work set by their school to complete but younger ones can still be kept busy in ways that help them learn.Reading, writing, drawing, sequencing, sorting and ordering are all simple to manage and great for learning.Do not be fooled by so-called ‘‘educational’’ online games — most are not unless they really make kids think.Keep telly-watching for ­evenings. With many programmes, there is not a lot of learning opportunities unless an adult is inter- acting with the child — maybe by posing a challenge such as “How many X did you spot ”Puzzles are good. Old- fashioned board and card gamesare fun and work the brain.Look out for those that are easy to learn but hard to play well, such as draughts, Ludo, dominoes, backgammon and chess.Simply sorting Lego into piles or boxes according to size colour is a great activity. Collecting ten objects that they think will float and trying them in the bath helps them test their own ideas.Taking pictures or writing and drawing the results turns a fun activity into a proper experiment.Do not forget to work their bodies too —you have a ­garden then four ten-minute sessions to run, hop, skip, jump or throw or kick a ball around are essential.If kids need to be indoors, then source some keep-fit or dance sessions on YouTube to work on together. If all  fails, use up some energy by dancing to loud music.Expect the children to be more involved in household chores than usual — a family that pulls together in tough times is a strong family.Expect the kids to tidy up after activities, help with the cooking, take on laundry and offer care of younger siblings — maybe helping them with ­breakfast or reading stories.Be sure to praise when they do things right or try .::  Everyone washed, dressed,   fed and ready to begin. Discuss with each child their day’s work and what they need to show you at the end.::   Literacy. If older children have   work set by school, they should do that. Otherwise this is time for reading for pleasure or to practise writing. Older children could write a book report, begin a diary, plan a short story or email friends and relatives.::  Hop and pop. It’s important   to move your body, so make time for a -minute dance-and-fitness break. Whack up the radio and get moving.::  A -minute snack break,   ­followed by maths, science and numbers. If older children have work set by school, they should do that. Otherwise, activities such as sorting, creating sets, counting or sequencing are ideal.Younger children can play at shops with real or pretend money. Things such as number puzzles and working on a simple family budget could work well too.:: Movement challenge –  star jumps,  continuous bounces on a trampoline,  rope-skips, a five-minute “keepy uppy”, ten press-ups. Make it challenging for each child.::   Have a break for lunch and   some time to relax.::   Inidual project. Let the   child choose something they want to become an expert in, such as ­dinosaurs, Vikings, mini-beasts, transport or flesh-eating plants. Avoid sport and pop cultureyou can.Encourage them to research their chosen subject, then write about it, draw some pictures, make a model and share what they have learned.::  Get crafty. Let your child   choose whether they want to draw, paint, knit, sew or build something.::  Forget electronic ersions  – as it’s time for your board game of the day..:  Make your own snack – but   maybe keep it simple..:  Reflection. What did I do   today  What did I do well  What will I do tomorrow .:  Crazy half hour hour. Get   some fresh airpossible, whether that’s playing in the garden, going for a family walk, or a jog.:-:  School ends. Time for the kids to relax.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government 24 hours save britains pubs
story: THE Government has  hours to save Britain’s pubs, industry leaders have warned as they sent a four-pronged ultimatum.In a letter to the Chancellor The British Beer and Pub Association said thousands of pubs will go under and hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost within days without immediate help from the Government.The industry body is demanding the Government underwrites at least  per cent of wages so pubs can keep staff on and easily reopen when social distancing restrictions are lted.It is also calling for immediate cancellation of beer duty bills and VAT payments that are due to be paid by March  for the last financial year.The BBPA is also asking Chancellor Rishi Sunak to immediately distribute the £, and £, cash grants promised to pub companies.And it is also demanding the Chancellor underwrites insurance costs for business interruption for a period of at least three months for the pub sector, with money being sent to insurers or to businesses directly.The industry body, which represents  per cent of Britain’s brewers and around , owners of pubs, warned Mr Sunak he has “no time to lose”.In the letter to Mr Sunak - titled “ hours to Save our Pub Industry” - BBPA chief Emma McClarkin warns: “Mass and permanent pub closures are absolutely inevitable in a matter of days without a meaningful support package.“Some of our members are already closing pubs and there is no guarantee that they will ever reopen. We don’t have weeks we have days to save the sector.”In a heartfelt plea she adds: “Pubs are the heart of the community and the social hub in all towns, villages and cities across the UK.“Urgent investment in our sector can deliver disproportionate s in this extremely worrying time.“The sector supports almost a million jobs across the country, many in less affluent areas.“These jobs are in imminent danger, companies will be required to act this week regarding redundancies. The social and economic value that the sector provides to the UK is under threat. There is no time to lose.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus every brit regardless means
story: NewsCoronavirus: Every Brit regardless of means could be paid Universal Basic IncomeA Universal Basic Income is being considered for everyone in Britain regardless of their income situation to combat coronavirus, said PM Boris Johnson - with experts warning of up to a million jobs at risk in the short termShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  MAR NewsPM Boris Johnson has revealed a universal basic income could be paid out to all Brits " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailUniversal basic salaries could soon be afforded to every Brit regardless of circumstances in an unprecedented move to battle the coronavirus crisis. Boris Johnson said one measure being mulled over by the Government is a aposuniversal basic incomeapos as a temporary fix to help protect workers and ensure they have enough cash during the Covid- breakout, reports the Daily Mail. This comes after calls from Labour leadership contender and shadow business secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey who said a streamlined cash measure was needed with the pandemic yet to fully sink in for most people.In the meantime, amendments to the current Universal Credit system are also being toyed with by the Treasury, among a range of other measures - while some experts say GDP could plummet by a fth before .  The PM has already vowed to safeguard private renters from eviction due to the virus, with landlords barred from starting the ball rolling on evictions for at least  weeks. Across the Atlantic, Donald Trumpaposs administration could give the go-ahead for monthly , payments to every US citizen as part of an billion injection to keep the economy from sinking. On Tuesday, UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £bn package to help businesses stave off ruin as the country goes into semi-lockdown with social distancing likely meaning certain sectors could be decimated without proper Government support.This could otherwise lead to swathes of job losses, particularly in London where one in seven people work in the tourism, hospitality and leisure sector. There are also fears that Government loans and aid measures - amounting to a £bn boost - will only paper over the cracks and that grants are needed to ensure proper futures for those companies at risk, while some have called for national insurance to be halted and VAT bills deferred as well.And with OBR financial watchdog suggesting stopping council tax and getting the state to pay for utility bills, Mr Sunak urged employers to postpone lay-offs until the full package has been reviewed. Some, including Adam Marshall, chief executive of the British Chambers of Commerce, have said the level of cash handouts and rates holiday to smaller firms - as part of a £million injection - would be great, but said the money needs to get out quickly. While Paul Johnson, director of the Institute of Fiscal Studies, believes the business rates holiday is unlikely to allow bosses to target saving jobs. He said instead delaying employer national insurance contributions or delaying bumping up the living wage as well as increasing Universal Credit Allowances could be needed.CBI boss Carolyn Fairbairn has suggested VAT be axed to free up £ billion, and that national insurance be reversed. The banks, meanwhile, have given the green-light for a three-month mortgage holiday for those most at risk.

title: coronavirus needs radical cure tories
story: NewsopinionCoronavirus needs a radical cure. The Tories need to take a big, deep snf of socialismBailing out billionaires might save businesses, says Fleet Street Fox. But people drive the economy, and theyre the ones who need helpShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email When last weekaposs Budget included a £bn deal to beat coronavirus, the headlines screamed: aposDr Feelgood to the Rescueapos.Today, after a £bn business bailout, itaposs the aposkiss of leapos. What no-one appears to have noticed is that the disease has got  times more expensive in the space of a week, and itaposs still in the post. We have had more than  months’ warning of the tidal wave coming our way. To start with, it was dismissed as just another flu, then blamed on bats, and finally an economic headache for eBay traders alone.But we were thick, and we were slow. Today that wave is roaring up the Thames, where after sucking a few poor souls to an early grave it’s going to wipe out those bits of the City still at work.Our economyaposs biggest contributors are services, manufacturing, construction, and tourism. Theyaposre all in shutdown. The governmentaposs big idea is to save them by bailing out the bosses - big and small - but they are ignoring the real problem. The vast majority of us may outlive the virus, but every single survivor is going to be violently mugged afterwards. The Prime Minister and Chancellor say it’s a bump in the road and we’ll be over it in  months. Medics say it’s more likely to be - months. Imperial College London says we won’t be in the clear for  months, or as long as it takes until there is a vaccine. If £bn was all it took when they thought there’d be a couple of weeks of it, and £bn had to be magicked up for  months, then the back of this beermat says that for a year and a half you’re looking at £. TRILLION of government bailout.Or four times what the banking crash cost us in . And remember - that’s just for businesses. Never mind the knock-on costs of healthcare, unemployment and sickness benefit, lost tax revenue and an economy that needs restarting.  It’s also a conservative estimate, considering our annual GDP is at the moment £.tn. Of course, it won’t be next year.After the -month mortgage holiday, the mortgage still has to be paid. After the government-backed, low-interest loan, it has to be ed, with interest. And after you’ve handed out a load of cash to every business owner from Richard Branson down to the local pub landlord, you may find they did not use it in the manner you hoped.The Daily Mail’s economic editor Alex Brummer wrote today:  “The lack of directly-paid support for employees, as outlined above, may prove to be an economic and political mistake. Relying on the kindness of bosses to keep paying wages on borrowed money, for a long time, is placing too much trust in their hands.” He added: A further package of measures which directly places cash into the pockets of British citizens would feel more real than promises of mortgage holidays and access to benefits.”Hooo-weee. Is this a call for a universal basic income I see before me, and in the Daily Mail of all places   But suddenly, the sort of radical socialism even Jeremy Corbyn didn’t have the blind optimism to put in his manesto is looking like a credible idea. There is no other way for the nation to get through an indefinite period of economic shutdown. The average Brit owes £, on credit cards. Mortgage holidays mean the banks will lose billions of guaranteed income. Rent holidays mean landlords default on mortgages, and we all stop servicing our debts the whole Tower of Banking Babel will fall. If staff are paid, rates are eased and tax takes a holiday, businesses can be mothballed. But customers cannot hibernate from this crisis -staff stop being paid, they stop being customers where. Take nursery schools. Fees are paid in advance for each term, so staff get paid regardless of how few toddlers turn up. But the new term starts on April , and how many parents, then, will be sending their children  How many nursery staff will still be in a job in a month’s time, and how many parents will be unable to go back to work   Fighting coronavirus is hard enough. But the real issue is how people get back on their feet afterwards. Chicken soup might get you out of bed, but it won’t pay the bills. If you don’t have a job, are on unpaid leave, are one of the .m self-employed whose savings just went up in smoke, you won’t be able to patronise the pub, shops and other businesses that just reopened.And the chances are this won’t be a -month thing. In China, factories are reopening, but m in-country migrants that form a massive part of its workforce havenapost turned up. When they do, there is a very real risk of a new wave of infections, and a new lockdown. In , the Spanish flu showed its head early in the year then ed with a vengeance in winter. If covid- does the same, we could be facing repeated global shutdowns until NEXT spring. If last weekaposs £bn looks puny and ineffective now, imagine how piddling £bn will look by then. Boris Johnson’s fiscal stimulus is, at present, the equivalent of offering half a paracetamol to someone who needs a ventilator. Itaposs just not enough. Itaposs not aposwhatever it takesapos, because what it is taking is the piss.At Prime Ministeraposs Questions today Labour MP Kevin Brennan said: On the matter of aposwhatever it takesapos, it takes more than a  word slogan, is what I would say to the Prime Minister. And in this case it actually takes a bit of war socialism we need to get money into the pockets of the workers. Has he seen Early Day Motion , which I proposed, about bringing in a temporary universal basic income to support workers and get money where it’s actually needed The PM replied: I hear the honourable gentleman loud and clear… and of course that is one of the ideas that will certainly be considered.First the Mail , and now this. A Thatcherite, Eurosceptic, Commie-bashing Tory PM, saying heaposs considering a universal basic income. Well Iaposll be...Of the  MPs who have signed that motion so far, none are Tory or Lib Dem. But that will change, when they start to see the price of not doing it.With a guaranteed amount in the bank every month, people can still feed their families. They can pay some,not all, of rent and mortgage costs, and when the shutdown ends theyaposll have the wherewithal to begin spending again. The government, too, wonapost have an expensive backlog of benefit claims to deal with. The only way for a nation to keep its head above water is for its citizens to each have a le jacket. The government is already the insurer of last resort, and faces a bill of trillions to mop up this mess. To abandon a single inch of its duty would be to destroy us, and it.Butit were to pay each of the .m households in Britain £, tomorrow, it would cost just £bn. Suddenly, radical socialism is cheap and reasonable. Even to Tories,theyaposre not too thick and slow to do the maths this time.

The children of key workers and those most in need will still be able to go in, the Government said – but it was not clear how this would work. Most pupils will notthis school year in an escalation in the Government’s coronavirus response. It came as the UK death toll climbed to  as another  people in England and one in Scotland died. And it emerged a lockdown of London is planned as early as next week as the infections race ahead in the capital. Multiple sources told the Mirror they expected restrictions to be hugely tightened, with businesses closed and restrictions on travel.  A senior Government source signalled it could come within days, saying: “It’s not going to happen today or tomorrow.” It took London’s City Hall by surprise, with a source saying: “We haven’t heard anything on this – this lack of information doesn’t sound like the best way to govern in a national emergency.” A mobile mortuary was set up in the capital to cope with expected deaths from the disease. But there was hope with news that a “game-changer” test to seean inidual has developed antibodies to tackle the virus is “coming down the track”. Announcing the closure of schools, nurseries, childminding services and colleges from tomorrow, Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: “They will remain closed until further notice. This will be for all children except to those of key workers and children who are most vulnerable.” From Monday all schools will be expected to open but only the children of key workers and those classed as vulnerable will be allowed to attend. Over the next two weeks headteachers will work out the best way to run a skeleton operation, with some teachers and children being asked to go to a dferent school than usual. But the head of the NUT union said the announcement left “more questions than answers”. The move will radically change le for almost nine million children, millions of parents and more than , teachers across the UK. The Prime Minister said exams will be cancelled but the government would ensure pupils get the qualications they need. However, he did not say how or what form that would take. Thousands of students will have university or college offers dependent on their A-level results. Clare Marchant, boss of universities admissions body UCAS said plans had already been put in place for this scenario. But it remained unclear how the new system would work with some teachers worrying that relying on predicted grades would disadvantage worse-off families. GMB chief Rehana Azam said: “More detail is urgently needed.”  Scottish leaders said there is no guarantee schools there would reopen before the summer. Schools in Wales will be re-purposed to help “people in need”. Elsewhere:Prince Harry and we Meghan want to help people cope with the mental stress by using their soon-to-be-rebranded @sussexroyal Instagram account to share resources. Prince William supported a national appeal to raise funds for those in need through the National Emergencies Trust. He said: “It will ensure the support reaches those across the UK who need it most as quickly and efficiently as possible.”A Navy hospital ship that supported operations to curb the Ebola outbreak could be used to treat coronavirus patients and ease pressure on packed NHS wards. Helicopters and other aircraft could be made available, with some , troops on standby. Scientists at the Defence Science and Technology Laboratory at Porton Down, Wilts, are working on fighting the spread of coronavirus. Those experiencing coronavirus symptoms, such as a cough or fever, should self-isolate for  days.You should stay at homeyou or or anyone in your household has a high temperature or a new and continuous cough - evenitaposs mild. Everyone in your household must stay at home for  days and keep away from others DO NOT go to your GP or hospital.Go to NHS.UK to check your symptoms and follow the specialist medical advice.Only call you canapost get online, you feel like you canapost cope at home, or your symptoms do not get better after the seven days. If you are pregnant you should call you have any concerns about yourself or unborn baby during self-isolation. Pregnant women are advised to contact their midwe, out-of-hours helplines or a maternity team who will provide information on whether you need to go to hospital. Retired and part-time police could be called on to help depleted forces, with voluntary police specials paid and erted from their day jobssickness hits the regular service. Donald Trump said the border between the US and Canada would be closed to all but “essential traffic”, and confirmed he plans to bar undocumented immigrants from crossing the southern border. He said America is on a wartime footing and that he sees himself as a “wartime president”. Some  Brits, most elderly, were stranded on a cruise ship off Brazil. British diplomats are negotiating with the Brazilian authorities to try to get the passengers off the Silver Shadow.What has been announced  Schools in England will shut to most pupils after lessons on Friday but remain open for kids of keyworkers. Schools in Wales close on Friday “at the latest”in Scotland they shut by the end of the week. They close in Northern Ireland from Monday. Special schools, private schools and nurseries shut too. Who will look after the children  Millions of children will be sent home meaning in most cases, parents will stay home to care for them. Asking elderly relatives to help out is not an option as over-s are at risk. Employers will be expected to make allowances for working from home.  Which children can attend school  Children of key workers which include NHS staff, police, social care workers and delivery drivers. A full list will be published today. “Vulnerable pupils” will also be asked to turn up - meaning those who either have a social worker, or an education, health and care plan. What about kids who have exams  All GCSE, AS- and A-Level exams are to be axed. The PM said pupils would get the qualications they need. Options include teachers submitting predicted grades. Thousands will have university or college offers dependent on results. Primary school SATS will be cancelled for Year  children. Teachers have to draw up home lesson plans. What happenskids get free meals  There will be vouchers for children eligible for free school meals. It could just apply for children who get means-tested free meals rather than infants pupils who receive them universally.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSchools across the UK will shut their gates from Friday in a landmark move to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. Millions of British children will be sent home - meaning their parents are forced to stay home too to care for them. And sending children to live with grandparents is not an option because they are most at risk from COVID-. It will radically alter millions of parentsapos lives - and mean GCSEs and A-levels are cancelled leaving millions of teenagers in limbo. But not all children are being told to stay away from school. Those of key workers - including police, NHS workers and delivery drivers - will still attend. The move was announced today as UK cases soared by  in a day to ,. The government admitted the virus was spreading more quickly than anticipated and needed drastic action. Here is everything you need to know.When are schools shutting in each region  Schools in England will operate this Friday and then shut their gates from the end of the school day. The below details mostly concern schools in England but many of them will also apply to other regions. Schools in Wales will close on Friday at the latest. The Welsh government said: From next week, schools will have a new purpose. They will help support those most in need, including people involved in the immediate response to the coronavirus outbreak. Schools in Scotland will also close by the end of the week. Schools are to close across Northern Ireland from Monday - with the potential to remain that way until summer.Are all schools affected  Yes. But the government hopes no schools will shut entirely, at least not at first. All schools will shut their doors to most pupilsfrom Friday. The Department for Education hopes all schools will remain open for some pupils . However, officials accept that as the virus takes hold, it may not be possible for some schools to remain open at all. Itaposs understood all schools will be told to stay open for at least two further weeks , which will give them time to work out alternative arrangements. This could give time to allow, for example, some schools to remain open and take another schoolaposs pupilsit has to shut. What about sixth form colleges, FE colleges and universities  Sixth form and Further Education colleges will also close from Friday.Universities however are not being told to close - although many suspended face-to-face teaching last week. Are all children affected   No. Children of key workers will still be told to go into school. Key workers include NHS staff, police and delivery drivers. That is not the exhaustive list of key workers and those three job titles are just examples. A full list of aposkey workersapos will be published by the Cabinet Office on Thursday. Vulnerable pupils will also be asked to turn up to school. That means children who either have a social worker, or an education, health and care plan.  No, not especially. Research so far suggests the younger you are, the less likely you are to have complications from COVID-. The death rate is tiny for the under-s. Chief Scientic Advisor Sir Patrick Vallance said children often wonapost even know theyaposve had the virus. The problem is thatall children are going to school they spread the virus more quickly and could pass it to their families and wider society. This is about a measure to protect all of us. Itaposs not a measure because thereaposs some specic risk to children, he said. Can I leave my child with their grandparents   No, notyou can help it. Older people are more at risk from the virus and the over-s, or people with underlying health conditions, have been warned to be particularly strict with social distancing. Boris Johnson urged parents not to leave children in the care of grandparents or older relatives who are at higher risk of becoming seriously ill with coronavirus. What will happen to GCSE and A-level exams   They will be cancelled. Exams will not take place as planned in May and June, Boris Johnson said. The Prime Minister said the government would ensure pupils get the qualications they need. However he did not say how or what form that would take. Thousands of students will have university or college offers dependent on their A-level results. We will make sure their progress is not impeded as a result of the decision weaposre having to take now, Mr Johnson said. It is possible universities could use predicted grades,they resume as normal in September, but this is not confirmed. Whatmy child gets free school meals   The Government will put in place a national voucher system for children eligible for free school meals. The exact details of this voucher system - including how to redeem vouchers, where and whether they are online or on paper - have not been confirmed yet. Details will only be issued in the coming days. It is thought this applies to children who receive means-tested free school meals in low-income families, rather than infant school pupils who receive them universally. However, we are double checking this with the government. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said the government has not ruled out making extra payments from the DWP to make up for the loss, but the first step was a voucher system. Asked for more detail Mr Williamson said: In order to make sure that every child who is eligible for a meal is able to access it we are moving to issue vouchers to every eligible child immediately from next week. I would like to progress to a stage where in some schools there are meals provided, but that depends on staffing in those schools. Will all teachers still have to go to work  We have asked the government to clary whether all teachers who are able to be in the school will be expected to. Naturally, some teachers will be unable to attend due to the need to self-isolate or due to illness. Itaposs thought the nature of teachersapos work - whether they will be teaching lessons to pupils who turn up, or whether it will essentially be a childcare- will be at the discretion of head teachers.

title: voice mirror act fast save
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Act fast to save jobs as , people become unemployedThe Government caused unnecessary panic dragging its heels on revealing package of support to protect workers while instructing people to miss employment to isolateShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionTough coronavirus measures needed to save livelihoods " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn estimated , people have lost their jobs since the virus struck. This number could easily quadruplethere is no urgent action from the Government. Boris Johnson may have acted with the best intentions but telling people to avoid pubs, restaurants and other meeting places has been a disaster for the retail and hospitality sectors. The Government is promising to announce a package of support in the next few days to protect workers during this challenging time. A better course would have been to have put these measures in place at the same time as the new guidelines. This is not just an economic priority but a social one. Many low-paid workers may face the choice of losing their incomethey stay at home or soldiering on to work where they risk either falling ill or infecting others. We should be following the example of Denmark, Norway and Austria where the state has agreed to underwrite the cost of salaries making sure people stay in work. Next, the Government must raise sick pay and improve support for the two million who earn too little to be entitled to it. Ministers must also raise benefits, end the five week wait for Universal Credit and offer support for those most in need. The virus does not discriminate so the Government should not discriminate in who it helps. In a bow to the inevitable yesterday it announced schools will close from tomorrow. This is not a decision taken lightly when it will cause disruption to millions.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOne of Britainaposs oldest women celebrated her th birthday in the pub and a sex shop despite the coronavirus panic and says the secret to longevity is to keep going in the face of adversity. Ellen Matthews was born on March ,  and has lived through  prime ministers, four monarchs and survived both world wars. The defiant pensioner says she has seen it all in her time and was not going to let the current COVID- outbreak stop her celebrating with friends and family. On Wednesday she enjoyed a glass of wine as well as afternoon tea at the Edge of Town pub in Northampton surrounded by loved ones. Ellen said she wanted the event to go ahead despite the coronavirus outbreak sweeping Britain, adding: You only die once. On visiting the adult store with her relatives, she said: Itaposs nothing I havenapost seen before. Known to most of her family as ‘Auntie Nelly’, she still lives at home in Wooton, Northamptonshire, despite having a stroke and only having limited use of her right arm. She has carers who visit her three times a day who Ellen says ‘look after her very well, but she often still manages to cook for herself. She said: “I have a very good appetite and I still manage to do little bits of cooking. “I eat good food, loads of vegetables and I do enjoy a glass of wine. “I have my faith, which is Church of England. When he chooses, I am going to go happily and at peace.” When asked what her advice would be to help others live a long and happy le, she simply replied: “Keep going in the face of adversity.” Ellen had a long working le, including as a nurse for premature babies at Northampton General Hospital and then working in care homes for seven and a half years.  She said: “I worked with little babies and I worked with older people until they died. I saw them in and saw them out.”  Great-grandmother of two Ellen was born in Ilford, East London, but was orphaned aged two after her dad was killed in France during the war and her mum died after her home was bombed. She was taken in by a foster family at five years old and went on to marry her teenage sweetheart Walter aged  in . They had two children together and lived in Northamptonshire, before Walter passed away from cancer  years ago. Ellen added: Iaposve done tremendousI donapost say so myself. Itaposs a good age and I still enjoy a laugh with my friends and family. I thoroughly enjoyed my birthday. I think I had a bit to drink, but it was my birthday so Iaposm allowed. It was first visit to a sex shop. It was quite an interesting experience. I didnapost buy anything, just for the record. There was nothing that took my fancy. Iaposve lived through two wars so wasnapost going to let the coronavirus scupper our plans. Its a nasty business though and I hope I survive it.

story: NewsCoronavirus: Couple broken as plan to tie the knot on their anniversary is shatteredDerek Nally, from Great Barr in Pheasey, West Midlands, and fiancée Gemma Stubbs are devastated after having to cancel their wedding because of the COVID- outbreakShareCommentsByKiro EvansAnna MacSwan:,  MAR NewsDerek Nally and Gemma Stubbs were set to tie the knot on Saturday " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Derek Nally, , and Gemma Stubbs, , were set to tie the knot on Saturday,  years to the day they first met. But they have now decided to cancel due to the flu-like virus which is now causing a global health emergency.  Derek, who is from Great Barr in Pheasey, West Midlands, said the realisation their big day might not go ahead dawned on them after Prime Ministeraposs press conference on Monday, where he asked the country to begin practising social distancing. That was the moment we realised we would have to rethink, he explained.Follow our LIVE blog for updates on the coronavirus outbreak We could have put a buffet out and people could look around and think ‘I’m going to get coronavirus’. Also the photographer is pregnant. She was originally quite happy to go forward, but when they said that pregnant woman was at risk, she cancelled. Derek, who works in the manufacturing industry and Gemma, a primary school cleaner, say they are devastated by the delay. They had chosen their wedding day to coincide not only with the anniversary of their first date in , but seven years since Gemma said aposyesapos to Derekaposs proposal in August . The couple - who have three children - were first introduced by Gemmaaposs mother, who met Derek at a social club he used to run. I met her mother first and we got on very well and she brought her daughter in to meet me, Derek continued. Weaposre broken. It has hit us both pretty bad. I think last night when we threw in the towel, there was a sense of relief, but also the realisation that all our hard work has been for nothing. I’m not going to say I’m depressed and ready to jump off a bridge, but it is definitely affecting my mood. I tried to tell my mum last night and she was in bits. Just thinking about it again has given me goosebumps.  But the couple are taking it all their stride and say they have no hard feelings. The people we spoke to have been really understanding of the situation - I have to give them credit, Derek said. They have offered not to charge us againwe can find a day that works for all of us. I definitely don’t blame the government. They are trying to put a plan in place for something that’s never happened before. When the advice was ‘wash your hands and sing happy birthday’, I was over the moon. Boris is going to get a lot of criticism for not closing down the pubs and clubs where we were going to have our after party sooner, but I can see them all being cancelled. The government has advised the British public to:Avoid pubs, clubs, restaurants and all social gatherings Cease all unnecessary travelEveryone should work from home where possible Mass gatherings and sporting events have been cancelled Avoid “all but essential travel” to more than  countries If one person in any household has a persistent cough or fever, everyone living there must stay at home for  days Pregnant women, those over , and people with certain health conditions have been asked to stay at home for  weeks Schools will remain open  The couple are now hoping they can rearrange their wedding for their next anniversary - even though this would mean waiting another year. Personally, it is not something we discussed just yet, but my plan B would be to do it next year, Derek added. Aim for the anniversary again but it just means waiting another year.The UK now has , confirmed cases of  coronavirus  after  more patients were diagnosed with the potentially deadly illness in the biggest day-on-day increase so far.

Other shocking images of pensioners looking for food in supermarkets with limited supplies have also circulated on social media. Lauren Taylor, , who took the photo of the gentleman, said she hoped the picture would kick the public into action to take care of the elderly. The mum-of-two explained that multiple aisles on the supermarket had limited supply. She said: It was awful and just really sad. That was only one aisle and the others were in a similar state of empty shelves. People were grabbing lots of the stuff that were still on the shelves. Itaposs really just sad and disappointing in society that itaposs got to this point. Everyone needs stuff, but he had been left with nothing. Supermarket giants have moved to limit the number of crucial items people can buy. Tesco said shoppers will be limited to buying just three products per line from Thursday. Chief executive Dave Lewis added all counter services will close, to free up staff to restock shelves, and a priority hour will be launched at larger stores between am and am every Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Stores that previously opened  hours, will also now close at pm each evening.  The move follows similar measures by Sainsburyaposs, Aldi, Asda and Morrisons, to ease stockpiling pressure amid the Covid- outbreak. Sainsburyaposs revealed it will only allow customers to buy a maximum of three of any single item, while Morrisons said it is limiting purchases across , lines. Asda also announced it is restricting shoppers to three items on all food and closing its cafés and pizza counters, while temporarily reducing the opening hours of all its -hour stores for re-stocking. Aldi has already introduced limits of four items per shopper across all products.  Tesco boss Mr Lewis wrote to staff on Wednesday: It is fair to say that we find ourselves in uncharted waters. Covid- is bringing a change to the UK and itaposs clear that lots of things are going to have to sht around in order to help us cope.At Tesco, we have been doing everything we can to keep business as usual, but we now have to accept it is not business as usual. In the last two weeks, we have seen signicant and prolonged increases in demand across all of our stores and this is leading to shortages in some products for some customers. It comes as Britainaposs supermarket chains are also launching action to help elderly and vulnerable customers, while ramping up operations to meet surging demand for home deliveries.  Sainsburyaposs became the latest group to offer priority home delivery slots to elderly and vulnerable customers, as well as exclusive shopping hours. Its supermarkets will only open to these two groups for the first hour of trading on Thursday, chief executive Mike Coupe said, but will open for an hour longer so other shoppers do not miss out. Sainsburyaposs Local convenience stores will not offer the service. Supermarkets have seen a huge rise in demand for delivery services, with no slots available until next month for both Tesco and Waitrose in some parts of the south east. The surge came as Transport Secretary Grant Shapps authorised a temporary relaxation, until April , of the driversapos hours rules to help deliver goods to stores across the country. It does not apply to drivers undertaking deliveries directly to consumers. Despite the doom and gloom surrounding the deadly pandemic, with London said to be on the verge of going into complete lockdown, there are some good news stories emerging to give people hope.The game-changer new antibody test to see who has already contracted and recovered from coronavirus but not shown symptoms is not far away, according to Boris Johnson.The PM said someone who has already had the virus will feel confident - thanks to the test - they are most unlikely to get it again and canto work. So for an economic point of view, from a social point of view, it really could be a game-changer. The Governmentaposs chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said Public Health England is currently undertaking in-house testing and is looking at ways of getting the much more widespread version out.Hopes that the experimental drug remdesivir could cure patients have been raised after a -year-old Italian man who had testedpositive was given the all-clear following treatment. The broad-spectrum antiviral is being tested in five Covid- clinical trials including by the US National Institutes of Health on  patients admitted to hospital after contracting coronavirus on board the Diamond Princess cruise ship in Japan. China, meanwhile, has recorded no new cases in Wuhan, where the virus first originated last year, or in the surrounding Hubei province. It has been  days, meanwhile, since the province itself reported any new cases - giving millions hope that the deadly virus is starting to be brought under control.  In a similar story, the small town of Vò in northern Italy where the countryaposs first Covid- occurred has had no new cases for days. The University of Padua, alongside Veneto Region officials and the Red Cross, launched a scientic study on March  which has consisted of testing all , inhabitants in the town.The project hopes to shed light on the history of the infection, the transmission dynamics and those most at risk. When the study started,  residents had the disease.A test does no harm to anyone, said the governor of the Veneto region Luca Zaia, describing Vò as the healthiest place in Italy, reports the .This is proof that the testing system works, he added.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe least popular foods abandoned on shelves by panic buyers include expensive brands of pasta sauce and low fat chips. While shoppers scrambled for pasta, tinned food and toilet rolls - panic buyers were less taken with Loyd Grossmanaposs pasta sauce along with novelty soaps - such as gin and tonic scented handwash. Branded versions of ready-cooked rice have also been left lining the aisles, with shoppers not willing to pay the surplus p for Uncle Ben’s. Non-dairy milks, such as oat and almond is still standing, while both long le and fresh milk are long gone. Precooked meats have been cleared out of some shops while fresh soups and scotch broth are set to rot on the shelves. Baked beans arenapost available, but their low-sugar alternative have been left for the latecomers. And clearly everyone’s eating peanut butter for breakfast in Bristol, while honey appears to be sticking around. The Gin and Tonic craze clearly doesn’t extend into favoured hand wash as £ seemed a little too much for those wanting to kill . bacteria. On Twitter, shoppers have noticed the stingy extent of panic buying. Attached to a photo of expensive soaps left on the shelf, @Nigelandthe said: “Meanwhile in Bristol, we’re obviously very concerned about coronavirus, but only up to the value of £. and not a penny more.” In Sainsbury’s, shopper @MrsSpalding said: “Even when there’s no veg left no one wants you, sprouts #panicbuying.”Major supermarkets including Sainsburyaposs, Tesco, Aldi and Morrisons have rationed how much of certain products customers can buy. Some have restricted purchases in-demand items like toilet roll, paracetemol and pasta, while others have brought in blanket bans on multiple purchases. Itaposs just one of a number of measures brought in by the nationaposs grocers, as pictures of empty shelves spread through social media like wildfire. Panic buyers have stripped shelves of everything they can - in some cases leaving just ice cream and chocolate Easter eggs - while huge queues snaked around some supermarkets ahead of opening on Wednesday.

Tabatha Stirling, from Leith in Edinburgh, was unable to find any pasta for her -year-old son Teddy, who has Aspergeraposs and a selective eating condition, due to panic-buyers emptying supermarket shelves. Teddyaposs condition is common in autistic children and means that certain colours, textures and smells can put them off eating, Edinburgh Live reports. Tabatha said she was initially not worried about panic-buyers stockpiling certain long le items but only realised the extent when she tried to go shopping herself:She said: “It really ramped up this week, I took my  year old after school to Sainsbury’s and it was shocking. After just a short while, the online community both on Twitter and Facebook showed support for Tabatha’s request, resulting in her receiving more than  messages and tweets of generous offers.Donors included restaurant chain Prezzo who invited Tabatha to visit their Edinburgh branch for a bag. Tabatha said: “I’ve had four packets sent to my house already and there seems to be more to come. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus survivors have told of the symptoms that led them to get a test for Covid-. As European nations crackdown on freedom of movement, and encourage people to work from home, what can you expectyou fall sick with the novel flu.Since the outbreak was announced in Wuhan, China, in December , medical professionals have been grappling to understand the virusaposs symptoms and how they can be treated, Somerset Live reports. Health experts say that the risk of becoming critically ill remains low and not everyone who contracts the virus will become ill. Those who do are likely to experience symptoms similar to that of a normal bout of flu. Now, the experiences of some of those that have recovered from the virus sheds some light on what we should prepare for. . Painful sinuses Painful sinuses are common when you get a fair few strains of a cold or the flu. Sinusitis can leave you feeling awful, both physically and mentally. Pain, most often paired with a dull pressure, generally occurs when your sinuses become inflamed and swollen. You may feel pain in your forehead, on either side of your nose, in your upper jaws and teeth, or between your eyes. While suffering with coronavirus, one man said that his sinuses were agony. Connor Reed, a resident of the Chinese city of Wuhan, is believed to be one of the first Brits to have caught coronavirus. Connor, who is originally from North Wales, contracted the virus in November  - a whole month before Chinese authorities officially announced the outbreak. After  days of feeling ill, recording his day-to-day le in his diary, Connor was treated at a hospital that diagnosed him as being one of the first people to get the new strain of coronavirus, Covid-. The -year-old English teacher described his symptoms starting out with just a snfle which he tried to medicate using hot whisky and honey, before succumbing to what he believed was the flu around a week in. In his diary he wrote: This is no longer just a cold. I ache all over, my head is thumping, my eyes are burning, my throat is constricted. He said his aposbones were achingapos and he had a aposhacking coughapos.  A few days later, the pneumonia had gone but he said he ached asIaposve been run over by a steamroller. My sinuses are agony, and my eardrums feel ready to pop. I know I shouldn’t but I’m massaging my inner ear with cotton buds, trying to take the pain away. Just a couple of days later, he reported feeling better. . Ear pressure As Connor discovered, another of the symptoms of coronavirus is pressure in the ears that make them feel ready to pop. But unlike Connor, you shouldnapost be pushing cotton buds into your ears to try and relieve the pressure - youaposll end up doing more harm than good. Because many of the virusapos symptoms are flu-like, this ear pressure is most likely to be caused by clogged up tubes in your ear thanks to all the nastiness of a virus inside your system. More scientically speaking, when the Eustachian tubebecomes clogged, you can feel fullness and pressure in your ear, as well as some muffled hearing and sometimes even earache. These ear congestion symptoms can also be caused by problems in your middle ear or the ear canal that affects the eardrum. So sometimes itaposs just a case of waiting for the virus to pass. . Thumping headache Again, a pounding or thumping headache is sometimes typical of a bad cold or the flu. But it can also be a symptom of other things too, such as tiredness, dehydration and even a lack of iron in your system.  So donapost go panicking straight awayyouaposve got a bit of a sore head. Make sure you drink plenty of water, get plenty of rest and try to relax. Take time away from your computer screen and avoid alcohol. Health experts are advising anyone suspected of suffering with coronavirus symptoms to take Paracetamol instead of ibuprofen, but keep yourself updated on all the latest NHS information, as things may change as more tests are done on the virus.. . Burning eyes The best way to describe the sensation of burning eyes is to compare it with the itchiness and irritation you would faceyou suffer with hayfever or other allergies. This kind of itchiness and irritation can also come about when you’re among smog, smoke, dust, mold and even animals. The only dference between these cases and the cases described by coronavirus patients, is the fact that the virus triggers this symptom and not an external factor like pets. . Constricted throat It seems as though patients suffering with COVID- experience a mixture of cold and flu-like symptoms, paired with typical symptoms of a small allergic reaction. A constricted throat can be due to swelling and inflammation, brought about after lots of coughing, which we know to be a common occurrence among coronavirus sufferers.  But a constricted throat can also be caused by an infection, allergic reaction, as well as a iety of other conditions. If you find yourself really struggling to breathe, swallow or find any lumps or bumps you’ve not seen before, you may need to be checked by a doctor immediately. So, it’s wise to keep monitoring your symptoms, in a diary like Connor, so you can see when things are beginning to change. . Aches all over It’s no secret that having a cold or a bout of flu normally comes with feeling achy. And coronavirus is no dferent.  Those falling ill with the virus have described aches and pains all over their body, not just as a result of blocked sinuses, ears or nose, but also in their arms, legs and chest too. Many people will find the current coronavirus outbreak a stressful time, too, and this stress and tension can also worsen these aches and pains. . Lungs that apossound like a paper bagapos If when you breathe, your lungs sound almost crackly, then this could be a sign of something more serious than just your average cold or flu. This sort of noise can often occurthe small air sacs in the lungs fill with fluid, as well as the air you’re breathing in and out. These air sacs filling with fluid can often happen as a result of pneumonia - which is a condition linked to coronavirus. If your breath sounds wheezy, this may be down to an inflammation of the bronchial tubes in your lungs. . Fatigue Another common symptom of Covid-, as well as cold, flu and many viruses in general, is feeling extremely tired or fatigued. Being told to rest is common when you’re ill, but feeling tired and not being able to sleep due to coughs and dficulty breathing, can make things all the more dficult. Jaimuay Sae-ung, , was the first Thai national to contract coronavirus in December last year. Despite having underlying health conditions, including a heart problem, Jaimuay survived the illness after doctors isolated her at a hospital in Thailand for treatment.  Her symptoms included a fever and a bad cough, but she developed pneumonia while in quarantine and her family were worried she may not survive. I only knewafter I came to the hospital, the mother of seven told Sky News. I felt a bit sad, a bit shocked, tired and fatigued and I couldnapost eat. Jaimuay said she argued with doctors and nurses at the hospital because she believed she didnapost need to stay there. After  days, her condition had improved and she was eventually discharged following two negative test results. . Lack of appetite Jaimuay also mentioned not being able to eat while suffering with coronavirus. The saying goes that you should feed a cold and starve a fever, so not managing to eat much may help to burn off coronavirus in the long run. Of course, those who are ill should be sure to keep their energy up. . A fever When coronavirus was first brought to people’s attention, a fever was one of the first symptoms to be on the look out for. It was later advised thatyou had been in contact with, or indeed lived with, anyone who had a fever, you should self-isolate. For some people, this is the only symptom of coronavirus they get. One young man, who did not want to be identied, is being treated for coronavirus in hospital after ing home from a short trip and noticing his temperature had risen, the Irish Mirror reports.  He told the RTE’s Claire Byrne Live show: “The only symptoms I had was, basically, the fever. I didn’t have any respiratory problem, any lung inflammation, any cough, any sneezing so was just the fever. “I actually feel great now. I had a fever for a couple of days and now from Friday, I don’t have any more symptoms and so I am just here in the hospital being tested for the virus. The man said he was a “little worried” but “not scared” and said he can not leave the hospital until two consecutive tests show he has tested negative for Covid-. He added: The only thing I would say is that it is boring, I am here and I just have to read, watch some movies and that’s the only things. Apart from that I am fine.” . Tight chest and coughing spells Another of the first symptoms of coronavirus to be identied, was a tight chest and persistent cough. Many scientists and health professionals have suggested that the water droplets passed through a cough or sneeze are the main cause of the virus spreading, which is why they have advised the entire population to wash their hands, cough and sneeze into a flexed elbow and use tissues wherever possible. Having these symptoms on their own has meant that some people with the virus have not considered the possibility that they may have Covid-. Those experiencing coronavirus symptoms, such as a cough or fever, should self-isolate for  days.You should stay at homeyou or or anyone in your household has a high temperature or a new and continuous cough - evenitaposs mild. Everyone in your household must stay at home for  days and keep away from others DO NOT go to your GP or hospital.Go to NHS.UK to check your symptoms and follow the specialist medical advice.Only call you canapost get online, you feel like you canapost cope at home, or your symptoms do not get better after the seven days. If you are pregnant you should call you have any concerns about yourself or unborn baby during self-isolation. Pregnant women are advised to contact their midwe, out-of-hours helplines or a maternity team who will provide information on whether you need to go to hospital.  Carl Goldman from Santa Clarita, who was on board the Diamond Princess cruise ship and later tested positive for coronavirus, said the virus aposhasnapost been that badapos. In an article for The Washington Post, he explained that he developed a fever and aposa bit of a coughapos during his flight back to America and was quarantined on his . I am in my late s, and the sickest I’ve ever been was when I had bronchitis several years ago. That laid me out for a few days, he said. This has been much easier: no chills, no body aches. I breathe easily, and I don’t have a stuffy nose. My chest feels tight, and I have coughing spells.  If I were at home with similar symptoms, I probably would have gone to work as usual. His treatment, he said, consisted of what felt like gallons and gallons of Gatorade. . Jet lag One coronavirus sufferer described her symptoms as feeling like jet lag - a temporary sleep problem that can affect anyone who quickly travels across multiple time zones. Your body has its own internal clock, or circadian rhythms, that sends signals to your body telling it when to stay awake and when to sleep. Similar to fatigue, the feeling of jet lag can make people feel that they’re not quite with it or even a bit spaced out. Bridget Wilkins, who lives in London, flew to Australia via Singapore for a friendaposs wedding last week - but is now quarantined in a hospital in Brisbane after testing positive for coronavirus.The -year-old said the symptoms she had suffered included a headache, a sore throat and tiredness.Without realising she had contracted the virus, she believed her symptoms were from jetlag after her long flight. Speaking to Australiaaposs NEWS she said she had still had symptoms but aposnothing more than thatapos. “There’s a lot of hype and hysteria on the news around coronavirus,” she said. “There should be. It’s very serious, particularly for the elderly and people with existing conditions. But I think we have to calm down, because for most people, like myself, it is just a long cold that we can shake off.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British team has received the green light to begin Phase II human trials of a drug that could help hospital patients fight off the coronavirus infection. The new hope of a breakthrough came as the death toll jumped by , taking the UK total to . The global race to find a treatment has been joined by a team from Southampton University.  They have been developing a drug known as SNG to help people with chronic lung disease fight off viruses and believe it could have the same effect on Covid-.  Up to ten hospitals will begin giving the inhaled drug to  patients next week and a further  will receive a placebo. If effective, it could be available for wider use within months.  Chief trial investigator Professor Tom Wilkinson told the: “The science definitely adds up. We’re learning a lot about the pandemic every day. “But that’s why we need to do this study, to understand whether the drug does work.  “If we see positive signals of safety and benefit in patients, we can then move rapidly into much larger studies and even into treatment. I’m optimistic and we will soon see the results.” The development comes as Boris Johnson revealed that Public Health England is close to perfecting an antibody test that will be a game-changer for diagnosis. Chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said Public Health England’s work on the antibody test is “progressing very fast” and will provide valuable insight into the pandemic.  Sir Patrick said: “It is a game-changer. It allows you to understand the proportion of the population who’s had this disease but hasn’t had symptoms.  “It’s going to be critically important to be able to monitor this disease well because only by being able to monitor it can we start relaxing measures again.”  The Government has announced schools will close from tomorrow and it is believed London could soon go into lockdown to slow the spread of the disease, with the Tube service cut back and  stations shut.

title: how survive coronavirus self isolation
story: NewsHow to survive coronavirus self-isolation - from music to what to watchThe thought of being stuck at home bored while self-isolating from suspected coronavirus is making some people more anxious than the idea of getting poorly we have some suggestions at keeping you entertainedShareCommentsBySiobhan McNally:,  MAR News" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Woman-sitting-on-sofa-with-mug-of-coffee-in-bookstore-reading-a-book.jpg"A good book is always interesting" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBeing forced to self-isolate means many of us will suddenly have a lot of unexpected free time – especially those who don’t feel ill. And the thought of being stuck at home bored is making some people more anxious than the idea of getting poorly. So,you’re wondering how to keep occupied, here are some suggestions for keeping cabin fever at bay... Movies Bond bosses have rightly decided that now is No Time To Die, so they’ve postponed the latest  movie. Other new film releases are also being pushed back as cinemas across the world are closing. Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email webnews@mirror    But there’s plenty to watch on streaming services like Amazon Prime, Netflix and Now TV, as well as a decent back catalogue on BBC iPlayer, ITV Hub and All .Family movies and rom coms are great to curl up with – preferably those cheesy ‘s ones or golden-age musicals in glorious technicolour.  Feel-good films . Anything by Richard Curtis – Four WeddingsNotting HillLove Actually , Bridget Jones. A Star is Born. Wall-E. Singing in the Rain. Paddington . When Harry Met Sally. My Fair Lady. Groundhog Day Guys and Dolls. Clueless Pick of the pandemics . Outbreak. Contagion. The Andromeda Strain. The Cassandra Crossing. Carriers Books Happily, you can stockpile as many books as you like without annoying anyone, but it might be worth avoiding the post-apocalyptic novels. Easy-to-read books or audiobooks will be soothing for anyone who’s unwell, while everyone  can get stuck into this year’s bestselling doorstopper – Hilary Mantel’s The Mirror  The Light.By the time you’ve finished that, the worst should be over. Why not set up a book club with your pals on a WhatsApp group  Or, better still, join the Mirror Book Club on Facebook.You can also treat yourself to a cracking real-le read from mirrorbooks – like Hold On Edna, the uplting story of the first baby born in our amazing ––.  Music Madonna and The Who are two of the big names who have already cancelled their tours. Many festivals are also expected to pull the plug this summer, and sofa-surfing is about to become the new crowd-surfing. So, put together your own apocalyptic Spoty list . Or listen to other people’s music lists and get some inspiration. Both BBC Radio  and Radio  have a concert timetable online at bbc, offering a iety of tunes from modern to classical. If it’s good enough for the kids, then it’s good enough for the grown-ups – YouTube has a staggering amount of old footage of concerts and pop videos to watch, and all for free. Netflix, along with other paid-for channels and video subscription services, have more concerts to watch than you have time left on Earth. Live-stream concerts have been getting more popular recently. And it’s very likely that, as we continue to avoid mass gatherings, many more acts will begin streaming on Facebook or via streaming apps. Doomsday playlist . Happy Birthday. It’s The End of The World As We Know It - R.E.M. . Skyfall - Adele . Radioactive -Imagine Dragons .  - Prince  TV Try to avoid too much daytime TV. Switch off after you’ve watched your intended programme, or you’ll end up mindlessly flicking through  stations, and become addicted to shopping channels. Now is the time to plan your viewing schedule. On Netflix, unsurprisingly Pandemic is trending, but costume dramas can be invaluable in times of national stress – Downton Abbey, Call The Midwe and the new Belgravia drama on ITV. Terrestrial TV has some cracking dramas coming up including The Nest , Honourand obviously The Salisbury Poisonings . And old favourites Line of Duty and Killing Eve are set to .  Cleaning This could be an excellent time for a good spring clean – or quaranclean – for those of us feeling OK but still trapped indoors. Cleanfluencers like Mrs Hinch, left, and Queen of Clean are two of the latest online gurus for people who like things spick and span. Instagram star and former hairdresser Sophie Hinch has a following of .million cleaning fans who call themselves #HinchArmy, which is just what you need in this time of war against germs.Meanwhile, mum-of-three Lynsey Crombie, aka the Queen of Clean, regularly talks dirty as the resident cleaning expert for ITV’s This Morning.  Exercise You don’t have to wear Lycra and watch a celebrity get-fit DVD, but you can do exercises at home every day to keep in shape. Check out nhs.uk live-well exercise free-fitness-ideas  for simple cardio exercise routines such as burpees, push-ups, lunges and planks. Also, you can fill two water bottles and use them as free weights for arm curls and overhead presses.

title: mum vows never visit lidl
story: NewsMum vows to never visit Lidl again after she was hit by falling ceiling tileMartell Watson, from Croydon, said a shop worker said not again when they saw a tile had dropped from the ceiling at the Lidl store in Thornton Heath, south LondonShareCommentsByDanielle ManningMatthew Dresch:,  MAR NewsThe -year-old was buying dinner for her son when a wet section of the ceiling fell onto her on March  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mother is aposappalledapos at how Lidl has treated her after a ceiling tile in one of the companyaposs London supermarkets reportedly hit her hand. Martell Watson, from Croydon, claims a worker in the Thornton Heath store said aposnot againapos when they saw what had happened.She was forced to complete the rest of her shopping with just one hand, with none of the staff offering to help her, MyLondon reports.The -year-old was buying dinner for her son when a wet section of the ceiling reportedly fell onto her on March . The mother said: “All of a sudden this thing just literally fell straight on my hand. After a minute and a half one of the workers came over and said, aposnot againapos.” She claimed that staff told her that another tile had fallen earlier that day but not hit anyone. Martell, who has been shopping there for five years, described wanting to cry when the wet tile slapped down onto her hand. The worst part of her ordeal, she explained, was how unsympathetic some of the staff were after her hand became swollen. She said: “I asked the managershe could get me something I could wipe my clothes and hands with. The manager didn’t really acknowledge what I was saying. “She askedI was OK and can I leave you now. I thought, aposwowapos. She swept up all the dust and she left. “I stood in that same position for about  minutes in total, maybe a bit more. It was only the security who askedI wanted a drink or a chair.” After a further wait, Martell said another manager filled out an accident report, but didn’t offer to help her finish her shopping. She said: “They askedI wanted to fill out an accident form and I said aposof course, isn’t that normal procedure apos  “He said head office would contact me and that was it. He didn’t ask me a recollection of what happened, nothing. That was the end of that.” Ms Watson said she asked the second manager for help completing her shopping, but was given no assistance. When she explained to him that she was shocked by the incident, he allegedly asked her why she was upset. She said: “How can you ask me why I’m shocked when something has just fallen from the ceiling on to me  “That made me feel like I wanted to cry there and then because I can’t believe I’m being treated this way. “I’m not saying you have to fall at my feet but, for god’s sake, you don’t want people to complain. You would think they would help you or try and make it better even though it’s already happened. “Nobody helped me. I didn’t see another worker after that. Needing to feed her son that evening, Martell carried on shopping, by now pushing the trolley with one hand. She believes she should have been allowed to skip to the front of the checkout queue to make it easier for her to get home. She said: “I’m just appalled at the way they treated me. It was a total shock and I can’t believe the way they treated me. “It’s your shop. I’m not saying it’s your fault but it’s your shop. It’s close to my work but I would never go back there after being treated like that.” Lidl has since apologised to Martell about the incident. A Lidl spokesperson said: “We were extremely sorry to learn of this matter and sincerely apologise to the customer for any distress caused.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Pride of Britain winner who suffered extensive burns to her face and body as a child has found love and plans to marry her “soulmate. Terri Calvesbert was not expected to survive after suffering % burns in a house fire when she was  months old. She was left with no hair, lips, nose or fingers and lost a foot. Terri endured more than  operations, and was presented with a Child of Courage award by the Duchess of York in . Now , Terri, is planning her dream wedding to fiancé Richard Holmes, , this summer. The mum-of-one said: “I’ve always wanted to get married but I never thought this would happen at my age, especially to me. In previous relationships my partners have never really understood me or what happened to me. “Obviously, I’ve only got the one leg now, but Richard took it really well and he understands me. He is everything to me. He’s my best friend and soulmate. “Sometimes it has been dficult to build relationships with people, especially when I was younger. But I’m much more confident in myself now. I’m really excited about the wedding.” Richard, who describes Teri as a “fighter”, said: “I could never meet a nicer woman than Terri. I can’t wait to marry her and I’m really excited about the big day.” Terri was injured after her mum, Julie Minter, accidentally left a burning cigarette near her cot in November . When firefighters found her they initially thought she was a plastic doll. She spent six months in hospital, and was one of only a handful of people in the world to have survived such extensive burns. Following the house fire in Ipswich, Suffolk, Terri needed over  skin grafts and went to live with her dad Paul Calvesbert.  The factory worker had split from Julie just two months before the blaze. She was left wracked by guilt and did not see her daughter for  years, when the pair had an emotional reunion. Terri, who has no memory of the night of the fire, said: “When it comes to that night in November, I kind of get a horrible feeling inside. But that’s the only time it really affects me. “What happened does stay with me, but I’m really proud of myself for what I have achieved.”Terri met Richard through Facebook five years ago and says they instantly “hit it off”.The volunteer RSPCA worker later fell pregnant with their daughter Poppy-Mae, now aged three. She added: “It’s scary to be a mum and I never thought I would be able to be one.
